commit_message:
Remove deprecated auth from GlanceImageService

* Drop the code block specific to deprecated auth in image
  deletion code
* Remove reference to deprecated auth in the auth_strategy
  config option help text
* Related to bp remove-deprecated-auth

Change-Id: Id0f4f287d33d01d54642fbc544ada9b7ef1b83ec

commit_message:
Remove microseconds before time format conversion.

Updates Glance scrubber so that it chops microseconds off of the
date format before parsing a time format string. This fixes
an exceptions that can occur when using scrubber with databases
like PostgreSQL which include microseconds in date strings.

Fixes LP Bug #1022369.

Change-Id: I2e9eb66052d8ce34438a4c1ba7a5174cc2385bcf

commit_message:
Disable swift3 by default.

- Disable swift3 by default but add a new service `swift3` to enable it.
- Fixes bug 1021150.

Change-Id: I6b635008659e1a77fdfce364dfceaca593273c54

commit_message:
Prevent service catalog injection in auth_token.

Updates the auth_token middleware to explicitly prevent
X-Service-Catalog headers from being injected into responses.
In general Keystone would override these with its own service
catalog... however since X-Service-Catalog is optional and
not all implementations/calls return it is good to be safe and
just remove incoming X-Service-Catalog headers if they are set.

Fixes LP Bug #1023998.

Change-Id: I9497937abd1b434b42b40bc943a508dd7f1a3585

commit_message:
Use the dict syntax instead of attribute to access db objects

To make the code style consistent, use instance["attr"] instead of
instance.attr in the code.

Change-Id: I766c714cb86d3b67ff9787bc50e5e20e37c9b574

commit_message:
Adds service_catalog to the context.

Updates the ContextMiddleware so that it stores the service_catalog
which from set via Keystone's auth_token middleware.

The motivation for this change is that we'll need access to the
'object-store' endpoint in order to implement swift tenant specific
storage.

Partially implements blueprint: swift-tenant-specific-storage

Change-Id: I0389e135f6683a353ae915b543d70f6ac1246b2c

'}, {'account_id': 449, 'date': '2012-07-11 18:33:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Now we're now interpreting IP address ranges in two different ways depending on what size.  If I specify IP/31 I get two usable ips.  If I specify IP/30 I get two usable ips.  That doesn't make any sense.

I think either nova-manage should make it incredibly clear from the documentation that when you specify IP ranges with /XX syntax that it's going to strip out high and low IP, and throw an error on /31 and /32, or implement this such that specifying an IP range with /XX gives you consistent results (in other words, includes the high and low IPs)."}, {'account_id': 4277, 'date': '2012-07-11 18:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I sorta agree with you but just following the ticket.  Does this mean the ticket is invalid?'}, {'account_id': 449, 'date': '2012-07-11 20:50:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I think it's a matter of deciding what is meant by a "/30" with regards to floating ips.  If I hand nova a "/30", do I mean the 4 IPs contained in that bitmask, or do I mean the 2 IPs represented by that CIDR "network" once the gateway and broadcast address are removed.  If we pick the former then we'll want to be generating an ip list that includes the upper/lower IP in the range. If we choose the latter then I think /31 and /32 should generate an explicit error, rather than the silent error currently produced.'}, {'account_id': 4277, 'date': '2012-07-11 21:00:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Would it make more sense if I changed the code to not handle /30 at all and therefore the only change would be the /32 (single ip)?  Although I didn't understand what the big deal with 'nova-manage floating create 192.168.1.101'  as apposed to supplying the /32."}, {'account_id': 449, 'date': '2012-07-11 21:07:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

As long as it's documented that we drop the high/low IP when you specify /XX and we handle /31 and /32 as an error (/30 would be valid, providing 2 floating IPs in this case) then I would be happy."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-12 04:47:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

In the interest of simplicity, I would suggest that it uses the same logic and if someone specifies an /31 or /32 that it simply prints an error message stating something like:
Error: The network and broadcast addresses are ignored, so no addresses were added to the database. If you want to add a single address, please specify the address without a /32 at the end.

I think it is ultra-confusing to have cidrs sometimes add the network and broadcast, and sometimes not."}, {'account_id': 4277, 'date': '2012-07-12 16:33:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Agreed.'}, {'account_id': 1071, 'date': '2012-07-12 17:30:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-07-12 17:36:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I'm happy with this change in general since it should follow what people generally expect CIDR should work like.

Just need to get assertRaises(Exception, ...) fixed."}, {'account_id': 1071, 'date': '2012-07-12 17:41:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4277, 'date': '2012-07-12 17:43:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

ack, ignore that.  I need to run pep8 tests before i submit these reviews'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-07-12 17:46:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Floating_ip create /31,32 shouldn't silent error

Fixes bug 1017682 the netaddr.IPNetwork.iter_hosts
method doesn't return any IPs when /32 or /31 and
should throw an exception instead of silent error

Change-Id: Id8875b6016a4dbb40b29d2f7687e6c35491e0129

commit_message:
add UDP protocol support for logger

When a syslog daemon fails and SysLogHandler cannot reconnect to
it, server processes (proxy, container, object, and more)
would start consuming 100 % CPU and stop responding to requests.
It is because the server process go into an infinite loop if they
fail to reconnect to /dev/log.
This problem happens only when using unix_sockets.

This change enables us to use syslog without unix_sockets and fixes bug 780025.

Change-Id: Ibcc99a1a148b1008036146bf3bd079a9be24982c

I'll do that, but wanted to get this up for review in the meantime to see if the approach is valid."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 00:42:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

I'm not that adding an exception is what we want here. It looks like it is failing on changing the startup back to manual if it doesn't exist, so why not just use the same logic that we use for the other commands. In other words, allow the startup change to be attempted, and just keep going on an error. Something like this:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/19333/"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-07-10 01:44:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Presumably 0 and 255 are the only possible error codes from the executable, which means we might as well just not check the error code at all, and always assume that the deletion worked, right? I think that if I open the device with something else, then the delete command will fail for a different reason that *shouldn't* be ignored, right?

Can you explain why handling it with an exception to the caller is "not what we want here" just for my future understanding?

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-10 02:26:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

They aren't the only error codes for the executable, so we prefer to be safe and and only skip the error on expected problems.

One fairly good reason for not using an exception is that your code is skipping the run of logout and delete which should both be attempted, even if the by-path mountpoint isn't showing up. I can imagine situations where a logout has happened already but the delete was missed for example."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-07-10 14:20:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 14:41:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-09 20:37:13.000000000', 'message': "When deleting an instance, avoid freakout if iscsi device is gone

It's fairly easy to get into a state where an instance is not running,
the iscsi infrastructure has been torn down, and the instance cannot
be deleted because the associated iscsi device cannot be successfully
removed.

This patch checks to see if the iscsi device is present before trying
to remove it, and if so, raises a known exception that the
destroy()/cleanup() path can ignore.

Fixes bug 1022520

It's fairly easy to get into a state where an instance is not running,
the iscsi infrastructure has been torn down, and the instance cannot
be deleted because the iscsi device cannot be successfully removed.
This patch ignores the associated return value for that scenario and

commit_message:
When deleting an instance, avoid freakout if iscsi device is gone

It's fairly easy to get into a state where an instance is not running,
the iscsi infrastructure has been torn down, and the instance cannot
be deleted because the iscsi device cannot be successfully removed.
This patch ignores the associated return value for that scenario and
marches forward in the teardown process.

Fixes bug 1022520

Change-Id: Ib28790892eebe341ac10a92250cf872605fefe9b

commit_message:
Updated HpSanISCSIDriver to use initialize/terminate methods.

This is based on Nirmal Ranganathan's patch for Nova-volume, which
added a new key 'host' for initialize/terminate volume connection
information in nova to fix bug 992729.

HpSanISCSIDriver should adopt the change in order to work properly.
Also added missing unit tests for the HpSanISCSIDriver.

Fixes bug 992729.

Change-Id: I9584811a340799161d8c9ae88b1def282380c9ad
Signed-off-by: Zhiteng Huang <zhiteng.huang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Set libvirt_cpu_mode=none in nova.conf.

This patch sets the libvirt cpu mode to "none" unconditionally.  Optimal
CPU performance isn't really critical with devstack.  Without this
option, we are getting some devstack failures on some of the cloud
providers used by jenkins.

Fixes bug 1023513.

Change-Id: I01dc89a3edc6f118e248a965db858b26acbfeafe

commit_message:
Fix Diablo Automation Chef link

fixes bug 923304

The chef cookbook location was no longer maintained and had moved.
This patch points to the new location, and removes a reference to
ubuntu maverick, which is no longer supported.

Change-Id: Icf8daa5ebc5d3f3587185a53340d6940850eb0f1

commit_message:
Support allocation pools for subnet

Fixes bug 1022227

Usage examples:

create_subnet --tenant_id <id> --allocation_pool start=1.1.1.1,end=1.1.1.10 <networkid> <gw>

More than one allocation pool can be added by doing the following:
--allocation_pool start=1.1.1.1,end=1.1.1.10 --allocation_pool start=1.1.1.123,end=1.1.1.125 ...

Change-Id: I313625b6a8c1da6eaca8b1943da52738978ed72b

commit_message:
Adds bootlocking to the xenserver suspend and resume

Bootlock prevents an instance from being resumed accidentally if the dom0
were rebooted or a whole slew of other possible interactions. We'd prefer to
keep suspended instances suspended.

Change-Id: I82fb734b79270aa87cd3bb08797885d5fda11f6b

1) How did you generate this .mailmap?

2) Why are some left-hand entries not prefixed by the author's name, whereas all your added entries are?

3) I really want .mailmap to be put in some kind of order, so that all entries for a particular person are in the same location in the file.  Alphabetical order, like with Authors, makes the most sense to me."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-28 18:19:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Also, it appears that openstack/common/setup.py differs from what is in openstack-common.

Can you reconcile the differences?"}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-06-30 04:48:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Kevin, responses inline ..

>> 1) How did you generate this .mailmap?
I came up with the content manually, making sure "git log --format='%aN %aE' return unique entries.

>> 2) Why are some left-hand entries not prefixed by the author's name, whereas all your added entries are?

This is necessary, if committers use different fullname with different email address. Let us take this example:

Andy Smith <code@term.ie> termie <github@anarkystic.com>

There are several commits using,
   "termie <github@narkystic.com>" 

... user/email. If we simply add following entry,
  "<code@term.ie> <github@anarkystic.com>"

... in .mailmap file, the git log command returns,
  "termie <code@term.ie>"

... as the intended result is,
  "Andy Smith <code@term.ie>"

... I added full name for similar authors.

>> 3) I really want .mailmap to be put in some kind of order, so that all entries for a particular person are in the same location in the file. Alphabetical order, like with Authors, makes the most sense to me.

I'll sort the .mailmap content, incorporate Johannes comment and post revised patch.

As we use email and fullname/email, if we sort .mailmap file, emails are listed on top, followed by fullname/email lines. If you intend to include full name for all records, let me know. I'll take this up in next patch. Scan through every entry and add Full name, by referring the git log.

Note, it's a first step towards automating the AUTHORS file generation. Once this patch goes in, I'll fix setup.py script and other scripts, as appropriate, similar to how we deal with other projects keystone, glance, horizon and quantum.'}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-06-30 04:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-30 05:02:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

commit_message:
Fix .mailmap to generate unique AUTHORS list.

As per 3456b667c38aa1d439482b9c95838aba6d3d6c5c, Monty
merged code to generate AUTHORS file.

With this fix, git log honors .mailmap specification,
irrespective of name/email combination used for commit and
generate unique entries in AUTHORS file.

* .mailmap
  Handle all full name/email combination to ensure following
  command return unique records.
   $ git log --format="%aN <%aE>"

Change-Id: I44f1db1a991fd312ab37455b44985281ed1d392f

subject: Add check for vm_mode in compute filter
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-28 15:38:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3752/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/5049/consoleFull : UNSTABLE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/1246/consoleFull : FAILURE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/1259/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/6699/consoleFull : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-28 16:00:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Unfortunately, having looked at the scheduling code in more detail, I think you might have just opened a can of worms here :-(

As you mention, the XenAPI driver has made use of a 'vm_mode' property to let it decide how to configure guests, though it not get used for scheduling (presumably the author assumed all modern Xen hosts support both HVM + PV at all times). Your patch will allow for that limitation to be fixed for XenAPI, as well as for libvirt based hosts.

A few weeks back there was a patch adding support for filtering hosts based on architecture:

  commit 31336b35b4604f70150d0073d77dbf63b9bf7598
  Author: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
  Date:   Wed Jun 6 22:45:25 2012 -0400

    Add CPU arch filter scheduler support

Rather than updating the ComputeFilter, that change introduced a new ArchFilter that was disabled by default. I'm somewhat inclined to prefer your approach of using the ComputeFilter, and the architecture filtering could be made to use that too, meaning it would be always available instead of a manually enabled add on.

The architecture filter patch was nice in that it relied on libvirt capabilities to determine the supported arch, returning the list of arches in all <guest> elements. Unfortunately this only works if you assume all <guest> elements have the same vm mode, ie all HVM or all PV. 

So as it stands both the arch filter and the vm_mode filter will fail in some circumstances, and if you try to enable both of them, then the problem is compounded

One final bit of fun, is that the global nova config options for libvirt have a setting "libvirt_type" which refers to the type of hyperisor to use (kvm, qemu, xen, etc). Since a single libvirt connection, can support multiple hypervisors (eg qemu://system can do both kvm and qemu).  Depending on your choice of hypervisor, you may limit the choice of vm_mode or architecture, or both. The libvirt driver only considers the hypervisor type per host, not per instance.

What this adds up to is a big a problem. All the code is considering, vm_mode, architecture and hypervisor type in isolation. In fact the only possible correct approach is to consider the while triplet (arch, hypervisor, vm_mode) at the same time, and to dynamically report this info from detected libvirt capabilities (or equivalent for other virt drivers).'}, {'account_id': 2697, 'date': '2012-06-28 22:05:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(not sure how to respond to comments in this tool...)

I tend to agree that the ComputeFilter should handle filtering on the tuple (hypervisor, arch).  But thinking about it more, I don't thing vm_mode is necessary.  I'd expect xen hosts in an OpenStack deployment to support both hvm and pv instances.  From the ComputeFilter perspective, it would be enough to know if the requested hypervisor_type and architecture is satisfied, along with the existing extra_spec check.

vm_mode is needed in the libvirt driver, similar to the XenServer one, to generate correct config for pv vs hvm instance.  I have patches for this that need refreshed, some cleanup, and testing before posting.

BTW, hypervisor_type in the host capabilities is currently set by calling _conn.getType(), which returns a hardcoded string in most libvirt drivers.  E.g. 'QEMU' from the qemu driver, 'Xen' from the xen driver, etc.  hypervisor_type in the instances properties would need a matching value, e.g.

glance image-update --property hypervisor_type=Xen <img-id>

Would you be receptive to a patch that adds filtering based on hypervisor_type and ignore vm_mode?  As for architecture, I suppose folding that into the compute filter (or making it one of the default filters) should be discussed with Chuck and the list."}, {'account_id': 2697, 'date': '2012-06-28 23:41:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

After changing the compute filter to use hypervisor_type, I recalled why I chose vm_mode in the first place.  hypervisor_type isn't included in the instance db record, and hence not available in the instance properties provided to the filters and virt drivers.  I'd need to add that to nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py if there is agreement on using this property."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-29 09:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> But thinking about it more, I don't thing vm_mode is necessary. I'd expect xen hosts in an OpenStack deployment to support both hvm and pv instances. 

I don't think I agree with this in general. If you are running nested virtualization, you may well only have 'pv' capabilities for "hosts". While this is an unlikely scenario for a production deployment, in my experience nested virt is valuable in development & testing scenarios. I don't think it unduly complicates life to make the compatibility check use the full triple (arch, vmmode, hypervisor), rather than just (arch, hypervisor).'}, {'account_id': 2697, 'date': '2012-06-29 14:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> If you are running nested virtualization, you may well only have 'pv' capabilities for "hosts".

Yes, good point.  Nested virtualization is certainly useful for developing and testing openstack! :)

I'll roll a patch to check the triple.  Thanks for the comments!'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-04 01:29:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Since this changes the behavior of ComputeFilter, can you please add "DocImpact" (no quotes) to the commit message?

The ComputeFilter is currently documented (very sparsely) here: 

http://docs.openstack.org/essex/openstack-compute/admin/content/computefilter.html'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-07-11 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-07-11 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 2697, 'date': '2012-07-12 18:08:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sorry for the delay, I was on vacation and just getting back to this.  I'm testing a revised patch based on Daniel's comments.  The patch has gotten quite large and needs to be split up IMO.  I'll think about how best to do that, finish testing, and submit a new series for review.  Thanks."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-28 15:25:34.000000000', 'message': 'Add check for vm_mode in compute filter

Add a check in the scheduler compute filter to see if the compute service
supports the vm_mode specified in the instance properties.

As mentioned in a previous thread [1], there needs to be a way to control
scheduling of instances to an appropriate node in a mixed compute node
environment, e.g. KVM and Xen.  The existing vm_mode property, in conjuction
with the additional_compute_capabilities flag, provides a mechanism to filter
appropriate nodes.

Adding this check to the compute filter seems consistent with its
definition [2]:

"ComputeFilter - checks that the capabilities provided by the compute service
satisfy the extra specifications, associated with the instance type."

[1] https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg11507.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/doc/source/devref/filter_scheduler.rst

Change-Id: I1fcd7f9c706184701ca02f7d1672541d26c07f31
'}]
commit_message:
Add check for vm_mode in compute filter

Add a check in the scheduler compute filter to see if the compute service
supports the vm_mode specified in the instance properties.

As mentioned in a previous thread [1], there needs to be a way to control
scheduling of instances to an appropriate node in a mixed compute node
environment, e.g. KVM and Xen.  The existing vm_mode property, in conjuction
with the additional_compute_capabilities flag, provides a mechanism to filter
appropriate nodes.

Adding this check to the compute filter seems consistent with its
definition [2]:

"ComputeFilter - checks that the capabilities provided by the compute service
satisfy the extra specifications, associated with the instance type."

[1] https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg11507.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/doc/source/devref/filter_scheduler.rst

Change-Id: I1fcd7f9c706184701ca02f7d1672541d26c07f31

messages:
[{'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-07-04 06:13:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

Thanks for the doc John! 

Some comments in line, if you have a moment ...'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-04 08:48:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

Thanks for the feedback.
Hopefully addressed most of your comments.
Thanks,
John'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-04 08:49:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-04 23:29:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

A couple of typos, inline.

Also, I agree with John that just referencing DevStack isn't so helpful for readers. If it's too much work to fully document it here, Could you add links to the specific scripts in DevStack that install the XenAPI plugin and create the paravirtualized VM?

I looked at https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/tree/master/tools/xen and it wasn't obvious to me which scripts did what."}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-05 02:27:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

One more comment inline,'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-05 02:28:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That inline comment didn't show up. What I meant to say there was: Yes, please go ahead and open up a doc bug for getting more complete documentation for the stuff that's done in DevStack."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-05 09:59:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Thanks for the feedback, I have corrected those typos and tried to give a few more links around the DevStack install details.

I have also raised a new bug to track this section:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/1021224

I am keen to make the most impact I can, and comeback and add the "extra" details in a second pass. I have a new guy starting in my team, so hopefully I can get his feedback running through an installation to help inform my improvements to the documentation.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-05 11:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-08 01:31:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

I had one question inline. Also, it would be helpful for a newcomer to Xen to give some guidance on choosing which Xen implementation to use (XCP, free XenServer, commercial XenServer), especially for comparing XCP to free version of XenServer, which is probably how somebody new would start off. Is there a difference in features? Is it easier to get started with one of them? Other differences?'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-07-08 01:37:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Agree with Lorin's comments - fix those and you're good to go!"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-09 10:58:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

I have tried to clarify the XenServer term "storage repository"'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-09 11:25:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The install experience is very similar between all XCP and XenServer. It is currently quite confusing at the moment. I have added some extra pointers in the doc. Hopefully I can clarify the situation further in the near future.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-09 11:28:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-09 13:03:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
artial fix for bug 962103 by adding XenAPI VLAN docs

Look at adding XenAPI docs for VLAN networking,
including a diagram and split out general docs
from libvirt specific docs.

commit_message:
Enable quantum agents to work with global cfg.CONF

This implements blueprint global-config-support

A common configuration parse function is used by the service and the agent.

In the case of the service, when loading the plugin, the configuration file
will be appended to the existing cfg.CONF (this was originally created when
quantum.conf was loaded).

In the case of the agent a global cfg.CONF will be created.

This task is a prerequisite for the RPC integration into Quantum.

Change-Id: I24ef4a804578502bcce484f44dc55c8fe2aa913e

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-12 16:11:07.000000000', 'message': 'Block on instance delete until delete operation completes

Fixes issue #160

During deletion of a stack, following would occur:
delete stack
delete instance
delete eip or security group

When the last operation occurred, the instance is still present in OpenStack
making a deletion of EIP or security groups not work properly.  Serialize
the operations in resources.

Change-Id: I6e1613f5a6f5db485dd8a5f381d7a96afb58188b
Signed-off-by: Steven Dake <sdake@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Block on instance delete until delete operation completes

Fixes issue #160

During deletion of a stack, following would occur:
delete stack
delete instance
delete eip or security group

When the last operation occurred, the instance is still present in OpenStack
making a deletion of EIP or security groups not work properly.  Serialize
the operations in resources.

Change-Id: I6e1613f5a6f5db485dd8a5f381d7a96afb58188b
Signed-off-by: Steven Dake <sdake@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove broken old write_requirements.

We decided this code was a bad idea in the first place, but also
it's broken, and it's causing stable/essex changes to no longer land.

Also, sphinx depend was missing.

Change-Id: I8d6161402addd0763792d4e2e6780487b8df9e77

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-10 15:37:38.000000000', 'message': "Don't block instance delete on missing block device volume

It's easy to create an undeletable instance by specifying an invalid
volume id in the block device mapping. The instance errors, but
subsequent delete fails because the volume is missing. We already
ignore the DiskNotFound case during delete, so this adds a case for
VolumeNotFound.

Change-Id: Ibc516ee4452d088cddf10bbeb315697ce900e5c5
"}]
commit_message:
Don't block instance delete on missing block device volume

It's easy to create an undeletable instance by specifying an invalid
volume id in the block device mapping. The instance errors, but
subsequent delete fails because the volume is missing. We already
ignore the DiskNotFound case during delete, so this adds a case for
VolumeNotFound.

Change-Id: Ibc516ee4452d088cddf10bbeb315697ce900e5c5

commit_message:
Make lxc a little less racey.

Add error checking for lxc container setup. This will make
LXC container setup a bit more robust. It includes informing
the user is not setup properly.

Change-Id: I995d4be0658dee8d0fbeb6d85aee2477164a276b
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
heat engine : Store stack timeout in database

Store the TimeoutInMinutes common query parameter
value in the DB so it can be returned correctly
with show_stack/DescribeStacks
ref #125

Change-Id: I4ccc79b586087f61e415d5d2c24b7bd52844399a
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

I of course meant  self._def['vcpu'] above :-)"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-27 16:34:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

The commit message text really needs some serious improvement. If you want to give feedback to earlier review comments, do it by adding comments in Jenkins, don't pollute the commit message with random comments, since these will make no sense to whoever is reading the GIT log in 6-12 months time.

My suggestion is that the commit message should be changed to read like:

  "Adds diagnostics command for the libvirt driver

   This code provides an implementation of the get_diagnostics
   API for the libvirt driver. This API is invoked by the
   'nova diagnostic' command.

   There is no existing formal specification for what data items
   to expose from the 'get_diagnostics' API, so the XenAPI driver
   is used as an informal guide. The Xen implementation currently
   produces the following output:

      ....include the 1st data table you have in diagnostics.py...
   
   The new libvirt implementation will return a similar set of stats
   for guest CPUs, memory, disks and network interfaces, resulting
   in the following output

      ....include the 2nd data table you have in diagnostics.py...

   The implementation has only been tested with the libvirt KVM
   driver.

   In a future a formal specification for the required data
   format should be written and all virt drivers made to comply

   Fixes bug 986200.
   Change-Id: I92da392f43d0840ed31cfd88f54570ea5830bb4a"'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-28 13:09:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

I've update the code according to the comments, extended the fakelibvirt driver and fixed the commit message (sorry about the previous commit messages). The tests now run without issues. 

I'm also trying to get my hands on a setup with the latest libvirt drivers to sor t out the data given out by libvirt when dealing with memory and cpu. However, that might take a while. If at all possiblem, i'd rather submit this patch now and then commit another patch later if i have the chance to do so."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-28 14:20:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

[{'created': '2012-06-22 11:17:52.000000000', 'message': "Adds diagnostics command for libvirt.

Implements the diagnostic command for libvirt. Fixes bug 986200.

The code is submmitted under a separte file called diagnostics.py.
The only thing i haven't been able to perform is obtaining the
memory from libvirt. It always returns an empty dictionary({}). In
case someone manages to get anything different out of it, it'll
call the toString method on the result.

I've tested this with libvirt + KVM.

Change-Id: I92da392f43d0840ed31cfd88f54570ea5830bb4a

"}, {'created': '2012-06-27 14:56:20.000000000', 'message': 'Adds diagnostics command for libvirt.

Implements the diagnostic command for libvirt. Fixes bug 986200.

The code is submmitted under a separte file called diagnostics.py.
The only thing i haven't been able to perform is obtaining the
memory from libvirt. It always returns an empty dictionary({}). In
case someone manages to get anything different out of it, it'll
call the toString method on the result.

I've tested this with libvirt + KVM.

EDIT:
I've added all the suggestions i could from Daniel Berrange, but
since i don't have the method getCPUStats available and i can
only get the following ouput from dommemstat "actual 524288".

I've also changed the parâmeters from the test_get_diagnostics
method since it did not correspond to the information i received
from the code running with devstack. The test still fails
since the fake_libvirt being used with the test lacks certain
methods i need, such as vcpus(). See this thread in the
mailing list for more details:
https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg13754.html

Change-Id: I92da392f43d0840ed31cfd88f54570ea5830bb4a
'}, {'created': '2012-06-28 14:07:21.000000000', 'message': "Adds diagnostics command for the libvirt driver.

This code provides an implementation of the get_diagnostics
API for the libvirt driver. This API is invoked by the
'nova diagnostic' command.

There is no existing formal specification for what data items
to expose from the 'get_diagnostics' API, so the XenAPI driver
is used as an informal guide. The Xen implementation currently
produces the following output:

+----------------+-----------------+
|    Property    |      Value      |
+----------------+-----------------+
| cpu0           | 4.3627          |
| memory         | 1171088064.0000 |
| memory_target  | 1171088064.0000 |
| vbd_xvda_read  | 0.0             |
| vbd_xvda_write | 0.0             |
| vif_0_rx       | 3223.6870       |
| vif_0_tx       | 0.0             |
| vif_1_rx       | 104.4955        |
| vif_1_tx       | 0.0             |
+----------------+-----------------+

The new libvirt implementation will return a similar set of stats
for guest CPUs, memory, disks and network interfaces, resulting
in the following output:

+------------------+------------+
| Property         | Value      |
+------------------+------------+
| cpu0_time        | 2870000000 |
| memory           | 524288     |
| vda_errors       | -1         |
| vda_read         | 262144     |
| vda_read_req     | 112        |
| vda_write        | 5606400    |
| vda_write_req    | 376        |
| vnet0_rx         | 63343      |
| vnet0_rx_drop    | 0          |
| vnet0_rx_errors  | 0          |
| vnet0_rx_packets | 431        |
| vnet0_tx         | 4905       |
| vnet0_tx_drop    | 0          |
| vnet0_tx_errors  | 0          |
| vnet0_tx_packets | 45         |
+------------------+------------+

The implementation has only been tested with the libvirt KVM
driver.

In a future a formal specification for the required data
format should be written and all virt drivers made to comply.

Finally, the fakelibvirt driver has been updated in order to
support the methods required by the get_diagnostics method.

Fixes bug 986200.
Change-Id: I92da392f43d0840ed31cfd88f54570ea5830bb4a

commit_message:
Adds diagnostics command for the libvirt driver.

This code provides an implementation of the get_diagnostics
API for the libvirt driver. This API is invoked by the
'nova diagnostic' command.

There is no existing formal specification for what data items
to expose from the 'get_diagnostics' API, so the XenAPI driver
is used as an informal guide. The Xen implementation currently
produces the following output:

+----------------+-----------------+
|    Property    |      Value      |
+----------------+-----------------+
| cpu0           | 4.3627          |
| memory         | 1171088064.0000 |
| memory_target  | 1171088064.0000 |
| vbd_xvda_read  | 0.0             |
| vbd_xvda_write | 0.0             |
| vif_0_rx       | 3223.6870       |
| vif_0_tx       | 0.0             |
| vif_1_rx       | 104.4955        |
| vif_1_tx       | 0.0             |
+----------------+-----------------+

The new libvirt implementation will return a similar set of stats
for guest CPUs, memory, disks and network interfaces, resulting
in the following output:

+------------------+------------+
| Property         | Value      |
+------------------+------------+
| cpu0_time        | 2870000000 |
| memory           | 524288     |
| vda_errors       | -1         |
| vda_read         | 262144     |
| vda_read_req     | 112        |
| vda_write        | 5606400    |
| vda_write_req    | 376        |
| vnet0_rx         | 63343      |
| vnet0_rx_drop    | 0          |
| vnet0_rx_errors  | 0          |
| vnet0_rx_packets | 431        |
| vnet0_tx         | 4905       |
| vnet0_tx_drop    | 0          |
| vnet0_tx_errors  | 0          |
| vnet0_tx_packets | 45         |
+------------------+------------+

The implementation has only been tested with the libvirt KVM
driver.

In a future a formal specification for the required data
format should be written and all virt drivers made to comply.

Finally, the fakelibvirt driver has been updated in order to
support the methods required by the get_diagnostics method.

For those interested, below is the formula to extract the
CPU usage based on the CPU time. I've added it here for reference
since it's not used at the moment and it took quite a while
to locate it in the libvirt documentation.

  usage = 100 * (current_cpu_time - last_cpu_time) /
          (measurement_interval * (10 ** 9))

Fixes bug 986200.
Change-Id: I92da392f43d0840ed31cfd88f54570ea5830bb4a

commit_message:
Display better message on Keystone failure

Fixes #148

When there's something wrong with Keystone, Heat reported a rather cryptic
message. Now it indicates that the problem is with Keystone and passes
its response to the user.

Change-Id: I791b5bdfa68faa1b17daa67b911253d8bf8a2bb8
Signed-off-by: Tomas Sedovic <tomas@sedovic.cz>

commit_message:
Remove deprecated auth-related db code

* Remove user_*, auth_token_* and project_* db api
  functions (except project_get_networks)
* Remove User, Project, AuthToken, UserProjectRoleAssociation,
  UserRoleAssociation, and UserProjectAssociation db models
* Add two migrations:
  * 109 removes the project_id fkey from dns_domains
  * 110 drops tables that correspond to the deleted models
* Related to bp remove-deprecated-auth

Change-Id: Iaacae0e5c0050e94b92e16ab5d8129eadb56c5a7

commit_message:
Fix call to network_get_all_by_uuids().

Fix bug 986922

This patch fixes a typo in the network manager.  This function is part
of the db API, not a method of the network manager.

(cherry picked from commit cc05a8defbb0d36ae6531acd2c5a9677c2f7ce97)

Change-Id: I2b0769f69ec4f58cd22708070b5fa4037f856026

commit_message:
Fixing documentation style

  * The docs have looked terrible since I last pushed new style to them,
    I finally got annoyed enough to figure out why sphinx wasn't accepting
    my stylesheets.

  * Before: http://stsh.me/2Qr
  * After: http://stsh.me/2Qs

Change-Id: Ibafcf1bfdd30b5ccdebbeb4fa0a64b49353b231d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-11 22:46:08.000000000', 'message': 'Fix line length for pep8 compliance after cloning into other projects

There are a few lines that are close to the length limit so they pass
the PEP8 check under the common repository but fail the check after
the code is cloned into another project such as ceilometer. These
changes adjust the lines to give more space to allow the merge into
the other projects to go ahead without breaking the pep8 gating tests.

Change-Id: I33a05f5b51120114cc8ceffd0bf1b1ef462ed636
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix line length for pep8 compliance after cloning into other projects

There are a few lines that are close to the length limit so they pass
the PEP8 check under the common repository but fail the check after
the code is cloned into another project such as ceilometer. These
changes adjust the lines to give more space to allow the merge into
the other projects to go ahead without breaking the pep8 gating tests.

Change-Id: I33a05f5b51120114cc8ceffd0bf1b1ef462ed636
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

[{'created': '2012-07-11 22:38:13.000000000', 'message': "Add 'filedecoder' method to the jsonutils wrapper module.

Fixes bug #1017765

After version 3.3.2, the anyjson library will throw a KeyError if
filedecoder isn't present.  The filedecoder is just like the decoder
except it takes a file instead of a string, like json.load() instead
of json.loads().

Change-Id: I7bd012a7b4afa9b1ec987c3e6393cc922b5dadff
"}]
commit_message:
Add 'filedecoder' method to the jsonutils wrapper module.

Fixes bug #1017765

After version 3.3.2, the anyjson library will throw a KeyError if
filedecoder isn't present.  The filedecoder is just like the decoder
except it takes a file instead of a string, like json.load() instead
of json.loads().

Change-Id: I7bd012a7b4afa9b1ec987c3e6393cc922b5dadff

[{'created': '2012-07-11 22:38:10.000000000', 'message': "Improve exception from importutils.import_class().

The ImportError raised by import_class() attempted to tell you what the
original error was by just doing str() on the original exception.
Sometimes that's helpful, but sometimes a full traceback is needed.
This patch includes a traceback for debugging purposes.

Change-Id: I00cefb9ebf9d6a71ef491204d81765e30e7941f6
"}]
commit_message:
Improve exception from importutils.import_class().

The ImportError raised by import_class() attempted to tell you what the
original error was by just doing str() on the original exception.
Sometimes that's helpful, but sometimes a full traceback is needed.
This patch includes a traceback for debugging purposes.

Change-Id: I00cefb9ebf9d6a71ef491204d81765e30e7941f6

commit_message:
Add ability to get version information in python

* A user can access glanceclient.__version__ to get a string
  representing the version of the installed library.
* Add openstack-common's 'version' module.

Change-Id: Ib14c561d8ac0b126617a20acfbd5fdb61c54f2c7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-11 21:35:47.000000000', 'message': 'Speed up metadata server registration

If heat-engine and heat-metadata were started at approximately the same
time, such that heat-engine was not ready to receive the registration call
from heat-metadata on the first attempt, it would take a minute before the
next retry. Instead, start with a very short timeout (2s) and increase it
if the engine does not show up.

Fixes #159

Change-Id: Ie2efcce667f1dde9ae227a4bb19a1d6a2b7cf135
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Speed up metadata server registration

If heat-engine and heat-metadata were started at approximately the same
time, such that heat-engine was not ready to receive the registration call
from heat-metadata on the first attempt, it would take a minute before the
next retry. Instead, start with a very short timeout (2s) and increase it
if the engine does not show up.

Fixes #159

Change-Id: Ie2efcce667f1dde9ae227a4bb19a1d6a2b7cf135
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Refactors more snapshot code into vm_utils.

Simplifies vmops a bit while moving logic into vmutils where it better
matches how we've seperated concerns.

Change-Id: Ic6d7559903d0f809f4c90577f4a8c4a0857cae90

commit_message:
Add common plugin framework.

For blueprint novaplugins.

It turns out that most of the plugin framework applies equally well
to other projects, so it's going into Nova via common so that
other projects can pull it in with a minimum of fuss.

Change-Id: Ia4455a8ca0b8c1c3e4b0b9647e8cacaf0a47c914

commit_message:
Adding user password setting api call

Fixes bug 996922

This commit adds a user_crud module that can be used in the public wsgi
pipeline, currently the only operation included allows a user to update
their own password.

In order to change their password a user should make a HTTP PATCH to
/v2.0/OS-KSCRUD/users/<userid>
with the json data fomated like this
{"user": {"password": "DCBA", "original_password": "ABCD"}}

in addition to changing the users password, all current tokens
will be cleared (for token backends that support listing) and
a new token id will be returned.

Change-Id: I0cbdafbb29a5b6531ad192f240efb9379f0efd2d

commit_message:
Re-add nova.virt.driver import to xenapi driver

A recent commit 5dd9e6150c0bebaef53e23fff7e55a17ef694537 removed the
import when it was still used. Re-add the import back so the driver
works again.

Change-Id: I1487a1a171c0d35c2f6752b08620f745ba1df385

commit_message:
Remove glanceclient.AuthorizationFailure exception

The glanceclient.AuthorizationFailure exception isn't raised anywhere, so
remove it.

Counterpart of bug #1015940

commit_message:
Distinguish over-quota for volume size and number.

Fixes LP 1020634

Ensure that exceeding the allowed number of volumes is not
mis-represented in log messages and exception handling as
excessive space usage.

Change-Id: I71ec995c77bc447bfc9221084b057bd8d69a4513

commit_message:
Clarifying which vm_utils functions are private.

This clarification should aid in future refactorings by giving a hint of
which methods are not referenced outside of the file (except for test
stubs).

Change-Id: I574b2caa25d54969a1627fa69f101b2480152b08

commit_message:
If no password in env or command line, try prompting

Implements keystone portion of blueprint prompt-for-password

For security reasons, having the password on the command line
or in the environment is an issue for us. (See the blueprint for
details.) This change will simply make one attempt to prompt for
a password if (1) nothing was specified already and (2) there's
a tty available for the user to respond on. If we don't get a
password, then the existing error will be raised.

Remoted getpass from pip-requires, it's in the std lib

Tweaked a comment

Tweaked error message

Don't catch Ctl-C

Fix import to match conventions

Missed a tweak during the rebase.

Added suggested password prompt

Change-Id: I54bca2397da7bd366f7ac503e767b109efc093e7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-11 18:30:35.000000000', 'message': 'Optimise DB lookups by ID

SQLAlchemy caches objects in the database per-session, but cannot cache
queries. A query just generates a list of object primary keys, which is
then used to fetch the corresponding objects from the cache (if possible)
or database. Therefore a query which filters by primary key is a waste of
time, since it just returns (surprise!) the key we started off with. If we
have the primary key (in this case the id field), just look up the object.

Change-Id: I7123c12372b26c0e1b91b2496921c54d9d992cd8
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Optimise DB lookups by ID

SQLAlchemy caches objects in the database per-session, but cannot cache
queries. A query just generates a list of object primary keys, which is
then used to fetch the corresponding objects from the cache (if possible)
or database. Therefore a query which filters by primary key is a waste of
time, since it just returns (surprise!) the key we started off with. If we
have the primary key (in this case the id field), just look up the object.

Change-Id: I7123c12372b26c0e1b91b2496921c54d9d992cd8
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-07-11 18:30:35.000000000', 'message': "Add a helper class for metadata

With this patch we can now access resource metadata through the 'metadata'
attribute and have it always fetch the latest data from the database. This
reduces the chance of accidentally accessing stale data, since the metadata
may be updated in a different database session via the metadata server, by
always accessing it in one place.

Change-Id: Id411ae891d3eace746d16008a7d58bb19b4f652d
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

attribute and have it always fetch the latest data from the database. This

commit_message:
Add a helper class for metadata

With this patch we can now access resource metadata through the 'metadata'
attribute and have it always fetch the latest data from the database. This
reduces the chance of accidentally accessing stale data (due to the
metadata being updated in a different database session via the metadata
server) by providing a single implementation to access it through.

Change-Id: Id411ae891d3eace746d16008a7d58bb19b4f652d
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

subject: Remove key_name and config_drive in GET /servers/xxx to adhere to v2 core spec
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 20:05:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/4319/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/249/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/5562/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/1759/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/1771/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/3123/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-07-10 20:13:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

config_drive is used if you specified it when creating the server. It's necessary to enable file injection for non-xen hosts."}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-07-10 20:15:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure if the link (http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-compute/2/content/List_Servers-d1e2078.html)
says the current response is invalid though. First, there is no schema. Second, the response is an "example". Third, the xml says the name space is http://docs.openstack.org/compute/api/v1.1 not v2. Should we fix the doc or the code, or perhaps both?'}, {'account_id': 927, 'date': '2012-07-10 20:57:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Chris: definitely agree this shouldn't just remove config drive.  As config drive is something that is only supported in libvirt, and is not in the API, how do you think we should proceed?

We could turn config drive into an extension which would be on by default since its an openstack extension.  This has an issue because extensions are supposed to have an extension prefix which scopes it properly.

We could also turn it into an extension, and in this one case (and probably key_name) not add an extension prefix since while not documented it has certainly been around long enough that it is in the API in practice.  This would allow Xen users to turn off the extension and all other users to continue happily along.  There is one potential caveat here: if a libvirt installation is specifying a specific list of extensions right now, deploying code that turns this into an extension would turn off this functionality until they update their extension list.

Same question applies to key_name as this is tied to the key_pairs extension, I believe."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:35:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

+1 Gabe, I documented the config_drive case here https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/833331 and it looks like Mr. MacGown never got around to fixing it. Once that bug is fixed (and another bug is filed and fixed for the key_name attr) this review can merge."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:39:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think that core functionality exposed in the API should be implemented via extensions. If config_drive should be in an extension, so should injecting files/personality, and every other feature of OpenStack that isn't currently supported on Xen and KVM."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:43:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It comes down to what made it into the v2 spec. Nobody is saying it's not useful or core functionality. The spec is locked. If we want to expose anything more, we have to do it through extensions."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:45:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The config_drive code was added two or three months before Diablo dropped, so if it didn't make it into the "locked" spec per Diablo's release that's a spec bug not a code bug.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:50:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

No, the spec isn't determined by what ships in a release. If you're trying to do less work, we'll do it. It's odd for you to bring this up as an argument when months ago you accepted the bug as it is defined today."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:53:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The bug requested that the feature be documented as an extension, not that it be implemented as an extension. Core functionality or functionality that makes it possible to use core functionality doesn't belong in an extension."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:55:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Deployers of OpenStack need to be able to disable specific features, one of them being config drive. With our extensions mechanism, we can make it so zero extra real work has to be done in order to get what we want. I find it hard to believe that you don't want to make Nova easier to consume."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-07-10 22:01:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There are other ease-of-use concerns than just the person who deploys the cloud. That's a one-time event or as near to a one-time event as is negligible. A deployer should not be able to disable features exposed in the API that are there to support features that are exposed and documented in the API/spec. Feature parity and lack thereof shouldn't be exposed at the API layer."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-07-10 22:08:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Config drive is an extension to the v2 API. There are deployers who don't want to expose it to their customers through the API. We need to enable that."}, {'account_id': 4463, 'date': '2012-07-11 18:25:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

adding extension for key_name'}]

commit_message:
instance-type-extra-specs-extension

Added several operators on instance_type_extra_specs in compute_filter.py:

    = (same as vcpus; equal to or greater than)
    s== (equal as a string)
    s!= (not equal as a string)
    s>= (greater than or equal to as s string)
    s> (greater than as s string)
    s<= (less than or equal to as s string)
    s< (less than as s string)
    <in> (substring)
    <or> (find one of these)
    == (equal in a number)
    != (not equal as a number)
    >= (greater than as a number)
    <= (less than as a number)

For more information, please refer blueprint instance-type-extra-specs-extension.

Change-Id: I87dda0288ccf0623eeed393abba0078afd674af8

commit_message:
Rework the version consumer functionality.

Moved the version routines into a class for better structure.
Added caching/memoization logic so that pkg_resources/git doesn't get
called more than is necessary.
Added periodic-based caching that will only cause the meta info refs to
be checked at most once a day, to reduce network load for developers. (The
information in the meta refs should really only change once a month, and
this will only affect local developer workstation version reporting, so we
should be fine here.
Added a deferred version string class and function to allow for consuming of
the version string but doing the calculation only when it is requested,
based on test runs in glance.

Change-Id: I6a436c8817f6904959727a76d876b807ec545ee9

Needs to at least default to False.  Other inline things.  And I struggle with whether this makes sense to build into nova or not."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-07-10 17:51:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Do not merge

(1 inline comment)

Noticed the class name is not going to work for the extension.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:10:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (5 inline comments)

Ok, I've fixed the issues noted. As for why this is in nova: This is already in nova.the instance usage audit is currently implemented as a cron job run on one node. this does not scale, as we have seen.  So it is moved to a periodic task on the compute nodes.

This task needs to run only once per audit period, so it needs something like the task_log to check "Have I run yet this period". The task log is general enough to be used for other internal nova housekeeping tasks that need to run once every > periodic_task_interval timeperiod, and need something more reliable than an instance variable at the manager level. 

Because something like that is needed as  an implementation detail we get a monitorable task_log nearly 'for free' by adding an extension to check that everything ran. 

Since this Will be merged (in our private rackspace branch, if not here. It's a Requirement from On High for us.) I'd rather it be here and available for all to use if they need, rather than us having another diff to maintain. If there is a better way to accomplish this that can be done in the next few days, I'd be happy to have suggestions.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:11:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:30:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

> As for why this is in nova: This is already in nova.the instance usage audit is currently implemented as a cron job run on one node.

What was in nova was an optional script that people could cron... that wasn't very intrusive.  This is something completely else.  And it's essentially implementing monitoring in nova.

But, I get it.  The task logging stuff could potentially be useful.. and maybe it's a start to some <insert other name for orchestration here> work."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:30:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 21:32:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-06 18:38:55.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor instance_usage_audit. Add audit tasklog.

The instance usage audit cronjob that generates periodic
compute.instance.exists notifications is not particularly scalable.
It is run on one server and takes longer as the number of instances grows.

This change moves the generation of those events to a periodic task in
the compute manager. It also adds an api extention that can be used
by administrators to check for errors generating these events.

Change-Id: I856d3d0c73c34e570112f1345d306308ef20a9ae
'}, {'created': '2012-07-06 19:34:57.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor instance_usage_audit. Add audit tasklog.

The instance usage audit cronjob that generates periodic
compute.instance.exists notifications is not particularly scalable.
It is run on one server and takes longer as the number of instances grows.

This change moves the generation of those events to a periodic task in
the compute manager. It also adds an api extension that can be used

commit_message:
Refactor instance_usage_audit. Add audit tasklog.

The instance usage audit cronjob that generates periodic
compute.instance.exists notifications is not particularly scalable.
It is run on one server and takes longer as the number of instances grows.

This change moves the generation of those events to a periodic task in
the compute manager. It also adds an api extension that can be used
by administrators to check for errors generating these events.

Change-Id: I856d3d0c73c34e570112f1345d306308ef20a9ae

commit_message:
Fix resize polling.

The `--poll` option for resize is not working because it is looking for
`verify-resize` instead of `verify_resize`.

Change-Id: I824ee019047121d49789a8311a1b315aa36fa295

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-11 14:27:32.000000000', 'message': "Use compute_api.get_all in affinity filters.

Updates the affinity filters so they make a single compute API
call to lookup instance host information rather than single
lookups for each UUID.

This resolves a potential performance issue which can cause a
scheduler to hang while processing requests which contain large numbers
of UUID's in the scheduler_hints.

Fixes LP Bug #1017795.

Change-Id: Ie33378a992e53002c16b2d99135699b576f3d7e3
"}]
commit_message:
Use compute_api.get_all in affinity filters.

Updates the affinity filters so they make a single compute API
call to lookup instance host information rather than single
lookups for each UUID.

This resolves a potential performance issue which can cause a
scheduler to hang while processing requests which contain large numbers
of UUID's in the scheduler_hints.

Fixes LP Bug #1017795.

Change-Id: Ie33378a992e53002c16b2d99135699b576f3d7e3

of the resource within the specified stack.

creation of the nested stack resource (and hence the enclosing stack) also
fails.

commit_message:
Report errors from nested stacks

If creation of a nested stack fails, we need to raise an exception so that
creation of the nested stack resource (and hence the enclosing stack) also
fails.

Change-Id: Ic5eda7f8d044ed2c87fc0e785b1cd8fcf78071a4
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Split xenapi agent code out to nova.virt.xenapi.agent

This refactoring makes the split between driver methods and internal
methods clearer. It also makes all agent methods private instead of
making some private, some public and some both.

Change-Id: I6c6b405942e47a85816e10224d4e6d986a8b06dc

commit_message:
Use compute_api.get_all in affinity filters.

Updates the affinity filters so they make a single compute API
call to lookup instance host information rather than single
lookups for each UUID.

This resolves a potential performance issue which can cause a
scheduler to hang while processing requests which contain large numbers
of UUID's in the scheduler_hints.

Fixes LP Bug #1017795.

Change-Id: I30f434faf109058573ee41c4a6abce2e48939e8d

commit_message:
Remove unused find_data_files function in setup.py

find_data_files was copied in a while back to work around setuptools
deficiencies. It has since made its way into distribute, and we are using it
from there - thus do not need a copy in our tree anymore.

Change-Id: I8bc76a201c325571601ac8da292ebd5690668065

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-11 14:08:51.000000000', 'message': 'Speed up engine manager unit tests

Refactor the engine manager unit tests so that they all use a single stack
that is only set up once. This makes the tests run a lot faster, and also
makes them easier to write. Both should encourage increased testing.

Change-Id: I50d2ffff393d4049459c5c30e408961681c189c7
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Speed up engine manager unit tests

Refactor the engine manager unit tests so that they all use a single stack
that is only set up once. This makes the tests run a lot faster, and also
makes them easier to write. Both should encourage increased testing.

Change-Id: I50d2ffff393d4049459c5c30e408961681c189c7
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

information, so cache it in the Stack/Resource objects themselves.

Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Allow Status(Reason) access through Stack/Resource objects

It would be better not to have to go looking in the database for this
information, so cache it in the Stack/Resource objects themselves.

Change-Id: Id96fbd229898fecc8917a61f19480f70fc2135d9
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

Adding Better Error for Launching Instance

When there is no images available to launch
an instance from, I have added a better, more
educational error message for the user to see.

For a change this big the devref should be updated.

* Is it possible to have only one folder for filters?"}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:12:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Joe,

The idea with separating the location of the filters is to get a cleaner logical separation between what scheduler uses and more generic host filters that compute (or another caller) can take advantage of.

For example, compute does not care about availability zones or trusted filters.  It also does not received capability advertisements.

My thinking is that nova/host/filters would contain simple filters like RAM and disk checks that are pertinent to compute or scheduler.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:44:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:44:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:58:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Brian, in that case better naming would be helpful.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-14 03:59:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(10 inline comments)

Cool.  Some things inline.  Double check all of the logging messages.. I might have missed some that have the same problem I noted on a couple.

I'm not really thrilled with /nova/host either..  but I can't come up with an alternative suggestion.

One thought I have.. cells needs filters too.  But they are Cell filters, not Host filters.  However, the code to get the classes and so forth is nearly identical.  I wonder if we should have a base NovaFilter class.. perhaps in /nova/filters/__init__.py  with some of those methods that figure out how to load the classes.  BaseHostFilter could inherit from it.. maybe renaming it to just HostFilter.  This could be done after this patch, though.  I'm just mentioning it in case it gives some different ideas of directory names, etc.."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-14 19:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-14 19:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

My only real objections have been addressed, though there are several questions or statements I didn't see responses to…"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-18 20:25:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

This is my first pass through the patch and there's some low-level questions and fixes I commented on.

I understand the problem this is trying to fix and I agree it needs to be fixed.

The title is misleading in that it doesn't eliminate the scheduler races, it just to provides a failure to the scheduler to let it know it lost the race.

I'd like to see what other changes will be necessary to actually recover from the failure.

The reason being, is that I'm not completely convinced that this is the best solution for the problem yet. It seems that the goal is to retry after losing the race (which isn't implemented yet), but it seems like we should consider solving the more general problem of build failures rather than this one particular failure."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-19 23:14:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-19 23:20:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

The latest patchset has support for retries in the filter scheduler.  There's a configurable number of attempts to schedule each instance.  Let me know what you think of this approach and I'll be happy to add retry logic for the other scheduler implementations also. (chance, simple, etc)

Also, I'm definitely not arguing that this approach will solve all build problems.  These changes are to solve a very specific problem of being able to run multiple instances (or many threads) of the scheduler without automatically failing a build any time there is resource racing on a compute host.  This is a basic distributed systems issue to be resolved unless we care to simply send instances to error and fail back to the API's client."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-19 23:59:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Doesn't seem to work

oops.. nevermind.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-25 16:25:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-25 19:14:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: No score

(2 inline comments)

johannes has some comments coming.  I clarified the thing I commented on in here.

It'd also be nice to make the whole scheduling thing a little easier to follow...  I get why it works the way it does... with yielding lists of hosts...  but it caused me quite a bit of confusion.  I was going to let it go for future cleanup... but others may not agree with that."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-25 19:48:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I understand there is a race condition with the compute node reporting resources and the scheduler acting on those reports leading to instances being scheduled to compute nodes that end up not having enough resources.

Ultimately, I would have preferred to see a more generic solution to build failures instead of solving one particular source of build failures, but I'll assume we only want to fix this one problem for whatever reason.

This patch still seems unnecessarily complicated.

Anything that moves part of the scheduler functionality into compute just seems like a design smell.

Instead of moving part of the scheduler into compute, why not calculate a maximum amount of memory that can be used by the compute node in  the scheduler and pass that to the compute node. It can still serialize checks for resources and fail early but all of the policy still stays with the scheduler.

It should also make the changes much smaller while keeping compute and the scheduler separated still.

Or am I missing something?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-25 20:08:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Unfortunately filters can determine what is acceptable... and a lot of people apparently are oversubscribing ram.. as this is the default of the RamFilter.  We'd need to at least get ahold of the ram_allocation_ratio... if not the whole RamFilter.

We can solve the generic case here too.  But after we do that, we still need to address resource race conditions as best as we can sometime before image download and VM start else we have a lot of high build times for stacking-type scheduling rules.

I think I've been ignoring the generic case... because I keep waiting for someone to pick up and start doing this "orchestration" work I keep hearing about.  If it were up to me, I'd just re-cast to the scheduler on every single failure for now with some recursion limit.

As I said above, I think we'd still have to end up with something like this, though, or every single resource-type race condition has to wait for full image download before re-scheduling..'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-25 20:19:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I don't see how my proposed solution wouldn't work.

The scheduler calculates maximum amount of memory (host total memory * ram_allocation_ratio). It passes that as a predicate to the compute node during the run_instance call.

The compute node calculates the amount of memory used by existing instances plus this new instance. Fail if computed total > scheduler calculated predicate.

I understand the desire to fail fast and I agree with it. This patch attempts to do two things: 1) fail fast and 2) recover from that failure and reschedule. (Ideally this patch would split into two separate patches to make it easier to review)

I don't see why implementing those two steps requires moving all of  this scheduler code into compute.

If not only for keeping stuff simple, it's also a separation of concerns thing and keeping all policy in one place."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-25 22:48:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

The ram_allocation_ratio thing multiplies the total host ram... not the total ram desired.  Slight difference.  There's also a vcpu limit checking (w/ an allocation ratio) too (I don't recall the filter being moved for compute to access it yet in this patch... it's the CoreFilter).

We could pass those allocation ratios over...without all of the full scheduler filtering shenanigans...but then we're hard-coding some things on the compute side that happen in only specific filters on the scheduler side.

We'd also need the current logic of being able to add up all of the cores/ram we think is in use on the host... which is the logic in the host_manager (although this will be better in a follow up patch when we grab the info from the compute_nodes table).

I get your concerns.  I don't really like how complicated this looks either :)"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:05:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

We're talking about the same thing wrt to host total memory. Check my previous comment.

The compute nodes already calculate the total memory, cores, etc so it can put that into compute_nodes. I don't understand the need for another way to calculate the same information.

I feel like I'm getting some agreement that this patch is too complicated, but then I also feel like no one wants to do anything about it."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:13:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

If I didn't want to do anything about it... I would have approved the patch a while ago. ;)

So you propose we pass the allocation ratios to compute with the build and check with the compute nodes table?

I think there's further fixes needed for the compute_nodes stuff to ensure the free ram is accurate...  but I could be wrong.  I know we have race conditions with the scheduler and setting instance['host'] which is why we can't do it there.  This part can be investigated."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-06-26 16:04:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Work In Progress

Marking WIP while I investigate alternate approaches based on feedback.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-07-11 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-07-11 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

[{'created': '2012-06-12 17:22:45.000000000', 'message': 'Changes to eliminate scheduler resource races

resources on a compute host.

commit_message:
Changes to eliminate scheduler resource races

Multiple scheduler threads/instances can potentially race to claim
resources on a compute host.

Implements blueprint: scheduler-resource-race

This changeset includes the following:

1) Compute host will serially verify that it has the resources to
satisfy new instance build requests.  Build requests (run_instance) may
be rejected if insufficient resources are avialble.

2) Scheduler resource verification logic has been refactored to make
resource checking code re-usable by the compute host.

3) Retry logic for the filter scheduler implementation.

Change-Id: Ic040804d3d5f2548c34cc48ebb0e2442fa284ba8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-03 21:53:38.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid lazy-loading errors on instance_type

Works around bug 1018721

A strange interaction between eventlet and sqlalchemy causes
lazy-loading errors to pop up under heavy load in som unknown
situations. There is a reproducible lazy load error in the
instance_type lazy-load, so this patch works around it by
catching the exception and reloading the instance_type record.

We really need to track down the source of this issue, but this
is causing problems in real deployments, so this workaround
will at least get us by until we can track down the nastiness.

Change-Id: I450c598c31c416c7be341cbb8cd14e33c6bb2aec
'}, {'created': '2012-07-10 00:25:25.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid lazy-loading errors on instance_type

When instances are launched with a source group, the instance_type
is not lazy_loaded in properly.

The issue is intermittent because if another query has already loaded
the instance with a joined instance_type or the instance has not
yet been expunged from the session, then the load succeeds.

Therefore this failure only appears under heavy load. Adding an
explicit joindload fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I450c598c31c416c7be341cbb8cd14e33c6bb2aec
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid lazy-loading errors on instance_type

When instances are launched with a source group, the instance_type
is not lazy_loaded in properly.

The issue is intermittent because if another query has already loaded
the instance with a joined instance_type or the instance has not
yet been expunged from the session, then the load succeeds.

Therefore this failure only appears under heavy load. Adding an
explicit joindload fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I450c598c31c416c7be341cbb8cd14e33c6bb2aec

commit_message:
Remove deprecated auth code

* Remove nova.auth.manager -- AuthManager, User, Role, Project, etc.
* Remove nova.auth.dbdriver
* Remove nova.auth.ldapdriver
* Remove nova.auth.signer
* Remove arbitrary scripts and schemas in nova/auth/
* Remove nova/auth/novarc.template
* Remove or update affected tests
* Related to bp remove-deprecated-auth

Change-Id: Ide0fefd0ddf79ae1b3bb74cb242c2893575839e7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-09 02:38:49.000000000', 'message': 'Auth refactor.

Switch to using the self-contained django_openstack_auth
package which is a proper django.contrib.auth pluggable
backend.

Notable functional improvements include:

  * Better overall security via use of standard Django
    auth code (well-vetted by security experts).
  * Token expiration checking.
  * User "enabled" attribute checking.
