commit_message:
Auth refactor.

Switch to using the self-contained django_openstack_auth
package which is a proper django.contrib.auth pluggable
backend.

Notable functional improvements include:

  * Better overall security via use of standard Django
    auth code (well-vetted by security experts).
  * Token expiration checking.
  * User "enabled" attribute checking.
  * Support for full range of Django auth attributes
    such as is_anonymous, is_active, is_superuser, etc.
  * Improved hooks for RBAC/permission-based acess control.

Regarding the RBAC/permission-based access control, this
patch moves all "role" and "service"-oriented checks to
permission checks. This will make transitioning to
policy-driven checking much easier once that fully lands
in OpenStack.

Implements blueprint move-keystone-support-to-django-auth-backend

Change-Id: I4f3112af797aff8c4c5e9930c6ca33a70e45589d

commit_message:
ensure libguestfs has completed before proceeding

This is a more correct fix than the previous sync(1)
which probably only changed timings, masking the real issue.

The FUSE issue is referenced here:
http://code.google.com/p/s3ql/issues/detail?id=159
which in turn references this thread on the subject from 2006:
http://thread.gmane.org/gmane.comp.file-systems.fuse.devel/3903
And another case from 2008:
http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.file-systems.fuse.devel/6502

Fixes bug: 1013689

Change-Id: I36fd11d5f01562f65a6b6f07e759ea066490b067

commit_message:
flags documentation to deprecate connection_type

connection_type in nova.conf is deprecated for Folsom, provide
additional documentation in the flags to indicate this, and the
new compute_driver options

Part of bp:virt-driver-cleanup

Change has DocImpact for Folsom

Change-Id: Iaff658771b1e992304454368e66ee53f9a0480ff

commit_message:
Change order of os options to fix fedora install

The Fedora install guide was showing apt-get commands, which
obviously don't work on such systems.

This change alters the order in the os flag to display the correct
commands

fixes bug 1019124

Change-Id: I6311042eb46772b6e4b9db0d28ca418f70d11745

sorry, I thought I had commented on this yesterday, but perhaps I never pressed submit.

Hi Adam, great to have you participating.  

I suspect this code was broken by a previous style "clean-up" effort to eliminate backslashes.  I think we should just be able to surrund the multi-part line with another pair of parens to allow python to parse it correctly.  

Ultimately, I'm fine either way, as in F-3 we'll be replacing this version of the NVP plugin with a new version that we've been developing and using internally (which is probably why no one noticed this breakage).'}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-07-10 20:35:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 20:35:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Fix some syntax errors.

Some syntax errors slipped in with a previous pep8 cleanup to this file.
These errors currently prevent distro packages from installing.

Fixes bug 1023066.

Update: * Proper pep8 indentation.
        * Wrap in paranthesis instead.

Change-Id: I257fbc7f0d8287ac648f2ad23caa7536388486d3

commit_message:
Switch to common notifiers.

- Added notifier files to openstack-common.conf, merged from common.
- Import notifiers from common rather than nova.
- Removed nova-specific notifier code.
- Update some driver paths to refer to the new location within nova.

Should be a no-op, as the common notification code is freshly copied from Nova.

Change-Id: Icdf892bc3826b683fc74f22ead00939beda2859f

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Yong,

Although I understand that this can be regarded as data model-level issues, I still consider it more an authZ problem, for the following reasons:
1) although for most cases port/subnet owner must be == to network owner, there are cases in which this might not be true, such as the one represented by bp quantum-v2-public-networks.
2) if this behaviour is implemented at the data model layer, for instance in db_plugin_base, it will sort of 'elude' the API contract, as plugin implementors are not required to extend from db_plugin_base necessarily, so they might implement a plugin with a different behaviour.

However, I do not feel extremely strong about this point. Which reasons are leading you to believe this should be regarded as a data integrity problem? In this case however, I would probably enforce this as a foreign key constraint rather than in the way it is enforced at the moment."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

sorry to keep bringing things up here.  Just one comment inline about whether we should move this check to the policy module.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I tend to be of the view that this is an authz issue, not an integrity issue, but I don't think we need to resolve the disagreement before merging this.  The code is correct and clean, so I'm going to approve it, and we can decide we need to refactor into the policy model later if we need to (as Juliano points out, the assumption enforced here will be modified when we implement public/shared networks, which would be a good point to revisit exactly what module this code lives in.

Good work Juliano!"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think the policy.enforce should not enforce it. Policy mean authz, mean permission of the operator in context on the target action. This bug is talking about some integrity, not about authz.'}, {'account_id': 4381, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 4381, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4381, 'date': '2012-07-10 19:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

subject: Initial implementation of glance replication.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 2284, 'name': 'Eoghan Glynn', 'email': 'eglynn@redhat.com', 'username': 'eglynn'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-21 11:08:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

Thanks for the patch Mikal!

A few minor nit-picks in-line, and also a couple more meaty suggestions to consider:

1. This script is based on the legacy glance CLI model, which is on the deprecation path for Folsom. Would it make sense to base it instead on the newer python-glanceclient code? (which will ultimately replace the legacy CLI)

2. The main driver logic is based on walking *all* images visible to the caller in the source region and checking if already present in the destination region before uploading - would it make more sense to instead only pull down public images that match some constraint (e.g. newer than some 'marker' image or date-stamp, or fulfilling other criteria based on the image metadata or custom properties). I suspect in practice an admin might want to run the replication today, then again next week and only consider the images that have appeared or changed in the meantime, or alternatively only select the images marked as pending replication via some property (as there may be 1000s of images in total).

3. Should the updates to metadata on the older (previously replicated) images also be propogated?

Just some food for thought ...

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-05-21 12:47:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

> 1. This script is based on the legacy glance CLI model, 
> which is on the deprecation path for Folsom. Would it make 
> sense to base it instead on the newer python-glanceclient 
> code? (which will ultimately replace the legacy CLI)

Huh. This is news to me, but I don't spend much time in glance land. I'll take a look at this tomorrow.

> 2. The main driver logic is based on walking *all* images 
> visible to the caller in the source region and checking if 
> already present in the destination region before uploading 
> - would it make more sense to instead only pull down 
> public images that match some constraint (e.g. newer than > some 'marker' image or date-stamp, or fulfilling other 
> criteria based on the image metadata or custom 
> properties). I suspect in practice an admin might want to 
> run the replication today, then again next week and only 
> consider the images that have appeared or changed in the 
> meantime, or alternatively only select the images marked 
> as pending replication via some property (as there may be > 1000s of images in total).

Yep, that's a fair point. I think a custom property might be the way to go here, instead of introducing yet another database somewhere. I see the next step with this being to implement some sort of rules language where people can define replication filters. Perhaps we should add the custom property filtering code at the same time as that?

> 3. Should the updates to metadata on the older (previously 
> replicated) images also be propogated?

Yes, but that hasn't been something I've considered yet. I think its an obvious next step as well.

Finally, I think another thing to be consider is where the configuration file comes from. Perhaps users can somehow setup configuration for their images, and then the admin runs the replicator to enforce the rules that users provide. That would give us something close to the mesh replication framework that was being discussed during the dev summit.

Cheers,
Mikal"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-05-21 13:17:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I see the next step with this being to implement some sort of
 rules language where people can define replication filters.
 Perhaps we should add the custom property filtering code at
 the same time as that?

Sure, that's reasonable to address in a subsequent patch.

 Yes, but that hasn't been something I've considered yet.
 I think its an obvious next step as well.

Cool.

 Finally, I think another thing to be consider is where the
 configuration file comes from. Perhaps users can somehow setup
 configuration for their images, and then the admin runs the
 replicator to enforce the rules that users provide. That would
 give us something close to the mesh replication framework that
 was being discussed during the dev summit.

Interesting thought, though the simplest cases could probably be handled via command line args (e.g. the condition on the custom property that identifies which images need to be replicated, or the datestamp that acts as the cut-off point etc.)

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-21 16:22:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

Great start, Mikal! Please see a few nits inline to address (and one big "Uh?") :)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-21 16:22:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oh, and one thing I didn't mention is the lack of documentation. Could you add something to /docs/source/ about this new utility? You can do this in a followup patch if you prefer, but don't delay too long."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-21 16:32:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

(1 inline comment)

I should preface this feedback with the fact that I haven't actually run the script yet. Now that that's out of the way, I'll provide some feedback:

1) I don't buy doing this through the glance client code. I would much rather see it coded directly against the API. The client interface is allowed to present things and make them human readable, which might not always translate correctly back through an add command.

2) The names of the actions don't make much sense to me: count, live, master and slave. They don't even seem to match their descriptions. It would make more sense to use dump (master) and load (slave). Not sure on a better term for 'live' yet."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-05-22 00:03:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-05-22 00:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (7 inline comments)

Folks -- thanks for the review comments. I think I've addressed all the comments in the source code itself. Remaining things to do:

 - source documentation (per Jay)

 - unit testing

And in later reviews:

 - filtering

 - some form of configuration language

Please note that this code was intended as proof of concept only based on a mailing list thread. I'm more than happy to push it forward if you guys think the approach is worthwhile to continue with.

I'm not familiar with the distinction between "the client" and the API. This code was modelled on the documentation at http://glance.openstack.org/client.html . I see documentation about the REST API at http://glance.openstack.org/glanceapi.html but it doesn't mention any wrapper classes to handle things like creating headers for me. Does such a thing exist?

Is the desire to use the REST API instead of the client code a strong one?

Thanks,
Mikal'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-22 14:01:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think this is definitely something we should develop further as it will end up being very useful for many groups of people.

I'm pushing for using the REST API directly for two main reasons:

1) The client code you used to build this tool will be removed within the Folsom timeframe, so a good portion of it will have to be rewritten.

2) You're adding a dependency on have the glance client installed to be able to use this script, which isn't really necessary."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-05-30 16:02:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Don't want this to be auto-abandoned. Have you been able to work on this at all, Michael?"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-06-05 22:48:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sorry, I got super busy with other stuff for the last few weeks. I will revisit this in the next couple of days.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-06 17:45:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

No problem. I just wanted to make sure this wasn't forgotten about!"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-21 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-21 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

As for your comment about the glance auth strategy: I think you should cut down the scope of what this script is doing. At least at such an early stage, it doesn't need to know how to do everything it could. I'd like to see you cut out the keystone authentication in favor of accepting an auth token as a command-line option. You could probably remove the 'replicate' action for now as well, since that is still doable with dump/load. I'd love to get the basic functionality into the codebase so others can help improve it."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-07-03 22:52:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

commit_message:
Initial implementation of glance replication.

* Add the glance-replicator binary
* Initial implementation of bp image-replication

Change-Id: I7dabbd6671ec75a0052db58312054f611707bdcf

When https://review.openstack.org/7971 got merged (and fixed in
https://review.openstack.org/8504), it introduced a bug where a key
in the xenapi other_config would get set twice. The real xenapi would
raise a Failure exception in that case. So make sure the fake module
also does that to ensure similar bugs will get caught in the future.

Change-Id: Ie0151ffaf45dade930c3e8ff1279bfeab537bab2
'}]
commit_message:
Raise Failure exception when setting duplicate other_config key

When https://review.openstack.org/7971 got merged (and fixed in
https://review.openstack.org/8504), it introduced a bug where a key
in the xenapi other_config would get set twice. The real xenapi would
raise a Failure exception in that case. So make sure the fake module
also does that to ensure similar bugs will get caught in the future.

Change-Id: Ie0151ffaf45dade930c3e8ff1279bfeab537bab2

commit_message:
Generate request id and return in header to client

* Generate a uuid in RequestContext.request_id on init
* Present request_id in an 'x-openstack-request-id' header using
  process_response in the ContextMiddlewares
* Related to bp glance-request-tracking

Change-Id: Idd9b86661322250b6167a1ee23e5baae91066ff6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-28 17:23:56.000000000', 'message': "Set the default CPU mode to 'host-model' for Libvirt KVM/QEMU guests

Historically Nova has not set any CPU model for guests started with
the libvirt driver. This means they are all using the per-hyervisor
default settings for CPU model. With KVM/QEMU guests the model was
traditionally a very conserative choice which exposed minimal features.
This is significantly limits the performance of applications. Further
the model has changed over time, so the exact default model is
unpredictable. Switching Nova to use the host CPU model by default
should improve the out of the box performance & give a known
setup.

This does not impact migration compatibility, since the migration
code is already doing comparison checks against the source and
destination host CPU model, regardless of the actual model used
in the guest. In the future the migration code should be tweaked
so that it actually compares the current guest CPU model, against
the target host CPU model, which would potentially broaden the
migration compatibility pool.

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: I5b96e4532b6a960e1608dd6e19ae9d194379fb6a
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2012-06-28 17:40:33.000000000', 'message': "Set the default CPU mode to 'host-model' for Libvirt KVM/QEMU guests

Historically Nova has not set any CPU model for guests started with
the libvirt driver. This means they are all using the per-hyervisor
default settings for CPU model. With KVM/QEMU guests the model was
traditionally a very conserative choice which exposed minimal features.
This is significantly limits the performance of applications. Further
the model has changed over time, so the exact default model is
unpredictable. Switching Nova to use the host CPU model by default
should improve the out of the box performance & give a known
setup.

This does not impact migration compatibility, since the migration
code is already doing comparison checks against the source and
destination host CPU model, regardless of the actual model used
in the guest. In the future the migration code should be tweaked
so that it actually compares the current guest CPU model, against
the target host CPU model, which would potentially broaden the
migration compatibility pool.

Ensure the test_get_guest_cpu_config_none() test case runs with
the UML driver, otherwise it'll try to use the new default of
'host-model' defeating the purpose of the test !

Fixes: bug #1003373

"}, {'created': '2012-06-29 10:00:33.000000000', 'message': "Set the default CPU mode to 'host-model' for Libvirt KVM/QEMU guests

Historically Nova has not set any CPU model for guests started with
the libvirt driver. This means they are all using the per-hyervisor
default settings for CPU model. With KVM/QEMU guests the model was
traditionally a very conserative choice which exposed minimal features.
This is significantly limits the performance of applications. Further
the model has changed over time, so the exact default model is
unpredictable. Switching Nova to use the host CPU model by default
should improve the out of the box performance & give a known
setup.

This does not impact migration compatibility, since the migration
code is already doing comparison checks against the source and
destination host CPU model, regardless of the actual model used
in the guest. In the future the migration code should be tweaked
so that it actually compares the current guest CPU model, against
the target host CPU model, which would potentially broaden the
migration compatibility pool.

Ensure the test_get_guest_cpu_config_none() test case runs with
the UML driver, otherwise it'll try to use the new default of
'host-model' defeating the purpose of the test !

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model

commit_message:
Set the default CPU mode to 'host-model' for Libvirt KVM/QEMU guests

Historically Nova has not set any CPU model for guests started with
the libvirt driver. This means they are all using the per-hyervisor
default settings for CPU model. With KVM/QEMU guests the model was
traditionally a very conserative choice which exposed minimal features.
This is significantly limits the performance of applications. Further
the model has changed over time, so the exact default model is
unpredictable. Switching Nova to use the host CPU model by default
should improve the out of the box performance & give a known
setup.

This does not impact migration compatibility, since the migration
code is already doing comparison checks against the source and
destination host CPU model, regardless of the actual model used
in the guest. In the future the migration code should be tweaked
so that it actually compares the current guest CPU model, against
the target host CPU model, which would potentially broaden the
migration compatibility pool.

With this patch there is a new libvirt_cpu_mode="none" which
can be used to explicitly prevent any CPU model setting in the
instance XML. The default value None, will now default to
"none" for LXC/UML/etc, and "host-model" for QEMU/KVM

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: I5b96e4532b6a960e1608dd6e19ae9d194379fb6a
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix Zmq so it doesn't rely on nova flags

* Embeded newlines in logging makes me cry
* String formatting uses parens not curly braces
* Fix LP1023039
* Hard skip Zmq tests so jenkins passes. Someone will have to fix.

instead of a proxy / connection.

commit_message:
Properly track VBD and VDI connections in xenapi fake

The fake xenapi module correctly destroys VBDs when destroying a VM
but it won't destroy VBDs when destroying a VDI. If an exception
occurs during a spawn when running test_xenapi, then another exception
can occur which obscures the original (and likely more important)
exception. This can make troubleshooting test suite failures more
difficult.

Change-Id: I19aad7f39b0707893a04784faef90815f7b0effb

commit_message:
Preserve image properties on update

* By default, image properties should not be deleted on image update.
* A user can specify --purge-props through the CLI or purge_props
  as a keyword argument to ImageManager.update to override the default
  behavior and force properties to be deleted.
* Fixes bug 1022758

Change-Id: Ib079378cb765552fc29a66913aefbbcd934d2065

commit_message:
Reorganize context module

* Move RequestContext class to glance.context
* Move context middlewares to glance.api.middleware
* Update tests to reflect move
* Update paste configs

Related to bp glance-request-tracking

Change-Id: I289b546ec28c973a3022be779ce378ae2febb340

What component will continue to tests quotas for volumes?'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-07-07 19:59:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Quota management would be handled the same as it is currently in Nova. We already do a bit of the Quota checking in nova/volume/api.py anyway, we'd need to move that in to nova/volume/cinder.py to match up.

Unless there's an objection, Quota management should stay in Nova as that's where all of the project info is already.

Also, WRT to the test I removed, the bulk of this test is instance/core etc, none of which belongs in Cinder.

We'll need a blueprint for Quota implementations in Cinder, I'll do that Monday unless somebody beats me to it or everybody hates the idea. :)"}, {'account_id': 838, 'date': '2012-07-08 16:45:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I do think that some form of quotas needs to remain within Cinder. Quota checks for volumes in nova is not going to be helpful. We need to apply quotas on volume creation rather than at attach time. Unless I'm missing something else, is there a need to delete it and add back later, unless it's going to be done differently in Cinder."}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-07-09 06:44:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Nirmal on Quota checking should stay in Cinder (when creating volumes) rather than in Nova (when attaching volume)."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-07-09 20:30:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-09 20:35:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Remove unused db api methods

  * Implements cinder blueprint remove-extra-dbapi-methods
  * Related to cinder initial-db-cleanup:
      Remove db api methods associated with removed tables
	  Modify/Remove tests associated with removed tables
	  Remove non-existing db API calls from volume/api

Change-Id: I60e0c6ffad9c78a29d56a27a04e9ec5ebaa1f251

Please ensure that HACKING's conventions for docstrings formatting are followed.  Docstrings should not contain leading or trailing spaces, and lines past the first should be aligned with the opening quote rather than the first line's sentence.

Please follow PEP257's convention for docstring language are followed, specifically to prescribe "...the function or method's effect as a command ("Do this", "Return that"), not as a description; e.g. don't write "Returns the pathname ...".

Please respond to received non-suggestion (Consider...) comments with either 'done' or an explanation as to why no change is required.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-07-10 16:21:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

In case the last comment was unclear, suggestion comments (from me at least, they start with 'Consider') are advisory only and require no response.  For all other comments, responding to review comments is desirable."}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-07-10 16:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Hi,
Some of my prior comments regarding the configuration can be ignored. I was running the utility with the wrong parameters. My bad and I apologize.
When running with the correct command line parameters the agent is up and running. It gets the IP address from the Quantum service. 
I nonetheless have some issues:
1. If there are problems with the agent then it continuously creates quantum ports.
2. When a new VM starts it does not receive its IP address. I see that the kill -HUP takes place (this is to load the new configuration file - which has the MAC address and the IP). I am trying to understand why this happens. I see on capture files that the DHCP requests arrive at the tap device for the dnsmasq.
3. When the dhcp-agent terminates, should it kill all of the dnsmasq sub processes? 
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-07-10 16:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

cool, vms now boot and get IPs :) 

Two issues seen in my testing so far.  

1) Invoking using the installed binary quantum-dhcp-agent installed into /usr/local/bin doesn't seem to work: 

nicira@com-dev:/opt/stack/quantum$ quantum-dhcp-agent --config-file /etc/quantum/dhcp_agent.ini 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/quantum-dhcp-agent", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('quantum==2012.2', 'console_scripts', 'quantum-dhcp-agent')()
TypeError: main() takes exactly 1 argument (0 given)

Instead, I must invoke the version of the script in quantum/bin/quantum-dhcp-agent directly.  I don't know enough about how the console_scripts stuff in setup.py works to comment more intelligently as to why though :) 

2) My VMs are incorrectly getting the IP address of their DHCP server (i.e., a random allocation from the subnet) as their gateway.  

It looks like you're setting an option in the options file to deal with this: 

tag:tag0,router,10.0.0.1

However, syslog shows dnsmasq complaining about reading this file: 

bad dhcp-option at line 1 of /opt/stack/data/dhcp/1a9459b6-8b40-40bc-8b58-f7622a61b1ec/
opts

I don't think this is a file permissions issue, as the opts file has the same perms as the hosts file, which dnsmasq is clearly reading correctly.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-07-10 16:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 16:21:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Doesn't seem to work

(1 inline comment)

Hi,
Thanks for addressing all of the comments. It goes like this:
1. OVS works well
2. Linuxbridge - the tap device for the dnsmsq was not added to the bridge (I am investigating - will comment when I find the root cause). In my opinion this can be addressed as a bug.
When testing #1 I also killed the dnsmasq process. The code addressed this. 
If the dhcp agent is terminated should we terminate the dnsmasq?
I'll give my +2 when the white space comment is addressed.
Great work.

subject: Makes all extension aliases lowercase
messages:
[{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-07-09 17:03:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Just trying to standardize one way or the other--I couldn't find any documentation indicating what casing was preferred."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-09 17:24:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/4176/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/150/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/5463/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/1660/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/1673/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/7510/consoleFull : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-10 01:37:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

seems fine but will require updates to docs and possibly horizon as well."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-07-10 01:51:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hmmm.

I feel like standardizing things is good but my first impression was that going with all upper case might be safer here... The reason I say this is it looks like most of the extensions which add onto responses already appear to use upper case... For example:


[root@nova1 ~]# nova show fad854a9-2998-4b18-a40a-3cf0625f1c9b
+-------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+
|               Property              |                          Value                           |
+-------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+
|          OS-DCF:diskConfig          |                          MANUAL                          |
|         OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host        |                          nova1                           |
| OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hypervisor_hostname |                        nova1.foo                         |
|    OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:instance_name    |                    instance-00000001                     |
|        OS-EXT-STS:power_state       |                            1                             |
|        OS-EXT-STS:task_state        |                           None                           |
|         OS-EXT-STS:vm_state         |                          active                          |

---------------------

The change you are making here would downcase all of these properties (which to me appear to mostly be UPPER CASE!). This seems like a potentially breaking change for end users.

Thoughts? Can you at least elaborate on why you choose lowercase?"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-07-10 15:16:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

I'm going to reevaluate the premise behind this change."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-07-10 15:43:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Yeah. . . no.'}]

commit_message:
Makes all extension aliases lowercase

In openstack compute extensions, some extensions are all lowercase and
some are all uppercase. This change standardizes on lowercase.

Change-Id: I202b936541c68733c94e68cdd1132a17a952f159

[{'created': '2012-07-05 18:51:01.000000000', 'message': "Fallback to fakelibvirt in test_libvirt.py test suite

If the native 'libvirt' module is not available on the host,
currently test_libvirt.py stubs it out to ''. While this
has sort-of worked for some test cases, others have had to
be configured to skip. As the complexity of the libvirt driver
increases, ever more tests will need to be skipped.

There is, however, the fakelibvirt.py module which provides
a dummy impl of the libvirt APIs for use in test_virt_drivers.py
With a few enhancements this fake impl is good enough to use
with test_libvirt.py too.

The constructor of libvirtError is changed to accept the
'msg' as first arg to match the regular libvirt module.
A few missing constants are added. The migrateToURI
method is stubbed out

All the previously skipped tests can now be enabled as
normal.

Change-Id: I15efbef8c676cc0e263a9c9bdd7b14dfb3771105
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fallback to fakelibvirt in test_libvirt.py test suite

If the native 'libvirt' module is not available on the host,
currently test_libvirt.py stubs it out to ''. While this
has sort-of worked for some test cases, others have had to
be configured to skip. As the complexity of the libvirt driver
increases, ever more tests will need to be skipped.

There is, however, the fakelibvirt.py module which provides
a dummy impl of the libvirt APIs for use in test_virt_drivers.py
With a few enhancements this fake impl is good enough to use
with test_libvirt.py too.

The constructor of libvirtError is changed to accept the
'msg' as first arg to match the regular libvirt module.
A few missing constants are added. The migrateToURI
method is stubbed out

All the previously skipped tests can now be enabled as
normal.

Change-Id: I15efbef8c676cc0e263a9c9bdd7b14dfb3771105
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make pep8 test work on Mac

find . -executable is not available on Mac OS X. We switch back to
the old -perm syntax to find files to test.

Change-Id: Iea58a249f282c98ae6cffbe8e6359f70f8b1d63f

Doug, I am not sure what version of tox is being run, but as of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8949 the same flag is in nova.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-10 13:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-10 13:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

There was a point in time when this flag depended on virtualenv defaulting to allowing site-packages (when the flag is true tox leaves off an option instead of explicitly adding the option to include site-packages) (see https://bitbucket.org/hpk42/tox/issue/32/option-system-site-packages-has-to-be). That caused problems with the qpid-related tests for ceilometer that I solved by changing our test program to remove the no-global-site-packages.txt from the virtualenv.

Do you know if the CI environment is running a version of tox with the fix for that problem?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-10 13:09:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

The flag is fine, and if we discover that it doesn't work with the version of tox we have installed now we can upgrade the servers."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 13:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 13:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

commit_message:
Use fake_libvirt_utils for libvirt console tests.

Updates test_libvirt.py so that it users fake_libvirt_utils.

This resolves an issue where the previous tests required
sudo to properly execute.

Fixes LP Bug #992805.

Change-Id: I9354b8facf82fb861dc2fe6da5fca102d8a33fbf

[{'created': '2012-06-26 21:01:16.000000000', 'message': 'Stop nova_ipam_lib from changing the timeout setting

 * Fixes incorrect logic for when timeout should be used. We
   want to timeout along with dhcp, and release immediately
   without dhcp
 * Also makes ipam_lib release fixed_ips after floating ips, as
   this is the way that the internal network managers do it.
 * Fixes bug 1014769

Change-Id: I687fac314264b8a89da128ed77c02d9b1ca140ff
(cherry picked from commit 45e98d415ec661ba7772ed2513f2a24ebe68f1dd)
'}]
commit_message:
Stop nova_ipam_lib from changing the timeout setting

 * Fixes incorrect logic for when timeout should be used. We
   want to timeout along with dhcp, and release immediately
   without dhcp
 * Also makes ipam_lib release fixed_ips after floating ips, as
   this is the way that the internal network managers do it.
 * Fixes bug 1014769

Change-Id: I687fac314264b8a89da128ed77c02d9b1ca140ff
(cherry picked from commit 45e98d415ec661ba7772ed2513f2a24ebe68f1dd)

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python27/368/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/7377/consoleFull : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-07-06 08:57:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Few thing are problematic here:

1. The code doesn't pass the PEP8 check.

2. How did you manage to get a 'STOPPED' status for an instance? As I see in nova, the status is evaluated from:

    "server": {
        "status": self._get_vm_state(instance),
....

    def _get_vm_state(instance):
        return common.status_from_state(instance.get("vm_state"), instance.get("task_state"))

and then:

    def status_from_state(vm_state, task_state='default'):
        """Given vm_state and task_state, return a status string."""
        task_map = _STATE_MAP.get(vm_state, dict(default='UNKNOWN'))
        status = task_map.get(task_state, task_map['default'])

for vm_states we have:

    vm_states.STOPPED: {
        'default': 'SHUTOFF',
    },

So I do not see how an instance could be in 'STOPPED' status - there is no such in vm_states. If an instance has state=vm_states.STOPPED, the returned status will be 'SHUTOFF'. Maybe I'm missing something, but then we need to add 'STOPPED' value the POWER_STATES dict in tables.py as well.'}, {'account_id': 2914, 'date': '2012-07-10 08:30:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2914, 'date': '2012-07-10 08:31:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Fix postgres VS mysql inconsistency.

When ordering the compute nodes, some have the `instance_cores` field empty
(that's ok, because an outer join is done). The problem is that MySQL puts the
nulls first (that's what we want), and PostGreSQL puts nulls last by default.

We just have to say explicitly we want the nulls to appear first.

Change-Id: If411c5f8a68749b09ed6bbb26ca7cc786b18480c

can modify image membership regardless of image ownership.

The motivation for this change is to be able to test image membership
when noauth middleware (UnauthenticatedContextMiddleware or
FakeAuthMiddleware) is being used and includes the following changes:

 * Added is_admin option to FakeAuthMiddleware.

 * Refactors the access checks into a common function called
   _check_can_access_image_members.

 * API unit tests which require is_admin=False for noauth were also
   refactored to use an improved FakeAuthMiddleware which supports
   is_admin = False.

   comparisons. Fixes issue where incorrect status code was returned.

Change-Id: I9d0e4679f9c0cb37f6df7c6f90460c22c37f3fbd

commit_message:
Allow admin's to modify image members.

Updates the v1 Glance API and Registry controllers so that admins
can modify image membership regardless of image ownership.

The motivation for this change is to be able to test image membership
when noauth middleware (UnauthenticatedContextMiddleware or
FakeAuthMiddleware) is being used and includes the following changes:

 * Added is_admin option to FakeAuthMiddleware.

 * Refactors the access checks into a common function called
   _check_can_access_image_members.

 * API unit tests which require is_admin=False for noauth were also
   refactored to use an improved FakeAuthMiddleware which supports
   is_admin = False.

 * Update RegistryClient to use get_status_code int for 204 status code
   comparisons. Fixes issue where incorrect status code was returned.

 * Updated members unit tests to support these changes.

Fixes LP Bug #1021740.

Change-Id: I9d0e4679f9c0cb37f6df7c6f90460c22c37f3fbd

'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-06-21 03:09:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Code looks good, but I wouldn't know how to use this feature. It was mentioned on a previous comment that DevStack's boot_from_volume exercise does not work with this (so that's no use), and there is no blueprint page that details how to set this up. 

I have nothing against the code merge per se, but I think we'd need more than just code at this point. Also, there are no unit tests, but I can see most people are fine with it.

So in a nutshell, I think it would be really worthwhile to have:

a) DevStack's exercise.sh fixed to work with xenserver/xcp
or 
b) Detailed set of instructions (on blueprint page, rst doc, etc) to show how to generate volume, boot from volume, etc.

Is this part of a different commit? I wouldn't think so, as this patch is pretty small."}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-06-27 00:21:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Armando, there are two reasons that the test from exercises does not work as is:
1. This one is relevant. The test script specifies mount point as "vda=" whereas the default disk prefix for xen is "sd". I think we need to handle disk prefixes in a cleaner way, rather than tweaking the code and simply allowing a "vd" prefix in boot from volume.

2. Less important. In the test, during the creation of the bootable volume, likely key injection fails, and the test stalls asking for a password.

If you have a bootable volume that you can test with, you can use the command in the script, except replacing vda by sda:
nova boot --flavor $INSTANCE_TYPE --image $IMAGE --block_device_mapping /dev/sda=$VOLUME_ID:::0 $VOL_INSTANCE_NAME

As before, the format of mapping is:
dev_name=<id>:<type>:<size(GB)>:<delete_on_terminate>'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-06-28 21:06:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-06-28 21:12:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-06-28 21:14:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Made the command mountpoint agnostic. So it can be run exactly as in the boot from volume exercise.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-28 21:35:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build successful

'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-05 10:32:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This look good now.

The error in devstack is now only because the default image doesn't get the key injection working properly, if I understand things correctly. This is a separate issue."}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-07-09 17:59:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-09 18:19:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

commit_message:
Boot from volume for Xen

Implements bp xenapi-boot-from-volume

Ensure boot from volume works for XenAPI (tested using XenServer).
1. Add strip_prefix to block_device to make the command mountpoint
agnostic.
2. Pass block device and delete on terminate information to driver
layer.
3. Add ability to recognize and boot from the specified nova volume.

Change-Id: If117087086eab809217d2b173f921bf9319a52c7

commit_message:
Fix KeyError 'key_name' when KeyPairExists raised.

Updates the Nova compute API to pass a key_name arg to the
KeyPairExists constructor. This fixes an issue where a KeyError
exception would get logged to Nova's api.log file if a KeyPairExists
exception was thrown.

Also removes the un-needed exception explanation argument from the
KeyPairExists constructor.

Fixes LP Bug #1022611

Change-Id: I83ecf3d392fef97649b298d1b732e1ff51145ae4

commit_message:
Fetch kernel/ramdisk images directly

Kernel and ramdisk images don't have a VDI allocated to them, so printing
the UUID in _fetch_image will show None.

[...] Fetched VDIs of type 'ramdisk' with UUID  'None' [...]

Change-Id: I1113606a97b48518e1db61f737633140b0f5eccd

commit_message:
Keystone dep is not actually needed.

An end user might need to install keystone to use the default config,
but glance testing uses stubbed out fakes.

Fixes bug 1021798

Change-Id: I99da75d29ba483125518760126d6145310ae1479

subject: Validate devices and partitions to avoid directory traversals
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:41:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/321/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-pep8/97/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/206/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/204/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:59:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I haven't checked, but I'm pretty sure a side-effect of this would be the swift proxy 500ing whenever you ask it to work with containers or objects named '.' or '..'."}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-06-21 13:06:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hrm, naive question: is there a reason we want to allow containers or objects to be named '.' or '..'?"}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-06-21 16:24:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Would this not be able to be filtered in the included name_filter middleware?

That middleware may need to be updated to filter substrings and not just characters.'}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-06-22 07:05:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hrm, I guess it'd work in the name_check middleware too. It's not always in the pipeline, though, so I'm unsure if it's fine to rely on this. I would think we always want the check.

But I'm happy to update the middleware instead if people feel it's a best approach."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-06-22 12:11:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't even know anyone who uses that middleware.  It seems to be there to force object names to fit some sort of domain-specific requirements?  If something's a security concern, I'd rather it be checked in the main part of the code."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-27 23:29:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not sure why the restriction of '.' but for '..' that seems like a client-side issue (python-swiftclient for example should check for such when downloading objects). If it's really not desired for an installation to have these in object names, that is what the name_check middleware is for. For many installations, these are valid in object names."}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-06-28 05:57:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

gholt: See Michael's comment about using name_check for this. There seems to be disagreement on where to best fix this :-) I'm also of the opinion that this shouldn't be optional if this is done for security reasons.

I can see the point in accepting '.'/'..' in object names, though."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-28 12:54:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sorry, I should've mentioned that I did see the comments and was providing my opinion."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-06-28 15:45:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oh, I agree with gholt that if you don't want them to be in object names, name_check would be an okay place to reject them.

I was saying ('.', '..') should be checked in the main code for variables that actually get used in disk paths.  Maybe the secure version of split_path could be used anywhere it's not splitting object and container names."}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-05 11:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-05 11:08:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/370/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-pep8/143/consoleFull : UNSTABLE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/249/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/250/testReport : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-05 11:20:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, here's a competely different approach, where we simply validate the devices and partitions when they come from a request. I think that's the only two variables that really end in path building later on.

We can also add some name_check thing as discussed too, but I don't think it's needed to fix the bug, so I'll take a look at this in a separate review."}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-05 11:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-05 11:37:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/371/consoleFull : SUCCESS

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/250/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/251/testReport : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-05 14:32:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-05 14:34:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-21 12:39:09.000000000', 'message': "Do not accept '.' or '..' in paths to avoid directory traversals

We do this in split_path() to avoid manual checking in each controller.

Fix bug 1005908

Change-Id: Ia545ba8f877e85b4b576d6d7d09d890877ea6d34
"}, {'created': '2012-07-05 11:06:11.000000000', 'message': "Validate devices and partitions to avoid directory traversals

swift.common.utils.validate_device_partition is a new function to check
that a device and a partition are valid. This means that they don't
contain '/' and are not '.' or '..'.

We use this new function every time we get devices and partitions from a
request.

commit_message:
Validate devices and partitions to avoid directory traversals

swift.common.utils.validate_device_partition is a new function to check
that a device and a partition are valid. This means that they don't
contain '/' and are not '.' or '..'.

We use this new function every time we get devices and partitions from a
request.

Fix bug 1005908

Change-Id: Ia545ba8f877e85b4b576d6d7d09d890877ea6d34

[{'created': '2012-07-09 15:45:06.000000000', 'message': "Fix config check

Two bugs have crept into the config checking in
tempest/tests/compute/__init__.py:

 * There's a leftover '% e' at the end of the construction of an error
   message. Probably copy/pasted from an exception handler somewhere.
 * There's an expression that's supposed to check that all of user name,
   tenant name and password are provided for an alternate user. However,
   the expression will be True (i.e. signal a problem) if the tenant
   /is/ provided, rather than if it were not provided.

This patch fixes both bugs.

Change-Id: I77eae72c9d306780c3e9e9ffd49b10666c178cca
"}]
commit_message:
Fix config check

Two bugs have crept into the config checking in
tempest/tests/compute/__init__.py:

 * There's a leftover '% e' at the end of the construction of an error
   message. Probably copy/pasted from an exception handler somewhere.
 * There's an expression that's supposed to check that all of user name,
   tenant name and password are provided for an alternate user. However,
   the expression will be True (i.e. signal a problem) if the tenant
   /is/ provided, rather than if it were not provided.

This patch fixes both bugs.

Change-Id: I77eae72c9d306780c3e9e9ffd49b10666c178cca

commit_message:
Add support for hypervisor-uptime.

Adds support for the new uptime call to the hypervisors extension to
nova.  This allows the results of "uptime" on the hypervisor to be
returned to the caller.  Note that currently, only XenAPI implements
the underlying method; if the version of nova uses another virt
driver, the result will be a 501 error.

Change-Id: I34cc92557e6d22705a5591e54404b32245dbe16a

commit_message:
Adds a script for tracking bug skips in tempest

New file tools/skip_tracker.py can be used to show the
status and priority of bugs that are marking test methods
for skipping, and instruct the caller to remove skips
on bugs that have been fixed in upstream. Output looks like this:

INFO: Total bug skips found: 52

commit_message:
Fix logic on alt user tenant/password check.

Updates the setup_package function so that the password/tenant
check for the alternate user works correctly. Previously it
was checking for a missing password but present tenant. It should
check for a missing password or missing tenant.

Change-Id: I3ab28baa13a66077d4a46e8fd2a40ec4869b9c70

Fixes bug 1022681

If deleting the kernel/ramdisk fails because the files don't exist
anymore, then ignore the error and continue. This will ensure that the
instance will get destroyed properly even if the files were deleted
outside of nova.

Change-Id: I5d1f95ea2a6f552c48efbb9e92bb36767df19e34
"}]
commit_message:
Ignore failure to delete kernel/ramdisk in xenapi driver

Fixes bug 1022681

If deleting the kernel/ramdisk fails because the files don't exist
anymore, then ignore the error and continue. This will ensure that the
instance will get destroyed properly even if the files were deleted
outside of nova.

Change-Id: I5d1f95ea2a6f552c48efbb9e92bb36767df19e34

commit_message:
Report size of image file in v2 API

Size will be None until image data is uploaded. The size attribute
will be updated to reflect the actual size. Related to bp api-2.

Change-Id: I577d8005b9ce60bf1470cda43413f0cdc034dbe1

subject: Adds swap and rxtx_factor to flavour documentation
messages:
[{'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-06-25 18:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah, finally figured it out, I added more info about rxtx_factor here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/6348/
in an extension about flavors. Feel free to borrow liberally.

swap
Amount of swap disk space to allocate to a server (in GB).

rxtx_factor
This property allows created servers to have a different bandwidth cap than that defined in the network they are attached to. This factor is multiplied by the rxtx_base property of the network.'}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-06-25 18:52:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Adds swap and rxtx_factor to flavour documentation

"rxtx_factor" and "swap" were added 6 months ago, but were missing
from the flavour documentation.

This change adds them to the xsd and xml/json examples.

fixes bug 999932

Feedback welcome - especially if you have an idea what rxtx_factor
is ;)

Patch 2 - explains rxtx_factor and fixes JSON example

Change-Id: Ib2e36156ed596532c0e625d8f45b14870dbc7d15

commit_message:
Remove swift_auth _reseller_check function.

Removes the swift_auth _reseller_check function. This function
prohibits a valid swift use case which allows users to access
URLs from another tenant to which user level ACL or public
access has been granted.

Fixes LP Bug #1020722.

Change-Id: I7ba784bed72dd943179d6b531712fdc13e4719b5

[{'created': '2012-07-09 17:56:15.000000000', 'message': "Fix 'instance %s: snapshotting' log message.

Update the Nova compute manage to remove the '%s:' string from the
log message. Nova already logs teh instance UUID for this log message
because we pass instance_uuid=instance_uuid to the logger so this
extra string isn't required.

Change-Id: I3fa276347d246e440917ac12d4fc5f88d90d7468
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 'instance %s: snapshotting' log message.

Update the Nova compute manage to remove the '%s:' string from the
log message. Nova already logs teh instance UUID for this log message
because we pass instance_uuid=instance_uuid to the logger so this
extra string isn't required.

Change-Id: I3fa276347d246e440917ac12d4fc5f88d90d7468

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-09 18:01:30.000000000', 'message': "Fix v2 API policy checks when keystone is in use.

bug 1022032.  There were significant errors in how
the policy framework was being invoked, but existing
tests did now show them, since they always invoked the
API with no keystone context.  This patch fixes those
issues and add a significant amount of test coverage
simulating API calls with keystone enabled.

As part of this patch, we also needed to add a tenant-id
attribute to the subnet object.  Furthermore, we
changed the API validation code to prevent tenant-id from
being changed with a PUT, since changing it after creation
could invalidate some of the create checks we're planning
on adding (e.g., that a port is being created on a network
owned by the same tenant).

Change-Id: I6da61f0d4ac3b259aa0afcd42cfa8e6ec1a9b035
"}, {'created': '2012-07-09 18:01:30.000000000', 'message': "Fix v2 API policy checks when keystone is in use.

As part of this patch, we also needed to add a tenant-id

Change-Id: I6da61f0d4ac3b259aa0afcd42cfa8e6ec1a9b035

commit_message:
Fix v2 API policy checks when keystone is in use.

bug 1022032.  There were significant errors in how
the policy framework was being invoked, but existing
tests did now show them, since they always invoked the
API with no keystone context.  This patch fixes those
issues and add a significant amount of test coverage
simulating API calls with keystone enabled.

As part of this patch, we also needed to add a tenant-id
attribute to the subnet object.  Furthermore, we
changed the API validation code to prevent tenant-id from
being changed with a PUT, since changing it after creation
could invalidate some of the create checks we're planning
on adding (e.g., that a port is being created on a network
owned by the same tenant).

Change-Id: I6da61f0d4ac3b259aa0afcd42cfa8e6ec1a9b035

[{'created': '2012-07-09 17:51:32.000000000', 'message': 'heat API: bugfix to XMLResponseSerializer

JSON wrapped in XML responses needs to be serialized
with json.dumps not str() or quotes get mangled and
json.loads fails to parse the result

Change-Id: I65c6ddf0be383e71bf8d05e7293b514269a27213
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
heat API: bugfix to XMLResponseSerializer

JSON wrapped in XML responses needs to be serialized
with json.dumps not str() or quotes get mangled and
json.loads fails to parse the result

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-26 16:55:04.000000000', 'message': "Return a 409 error when adding a second time a role to user/tenant

Fix bug 999594.

When a user/tenant pair already has a role and there is a request to add
the role to the pair, we can choose to either return 200 and let the
client feel it's alright to do so, or return a 409 error (Conflict) to
inform the client of the pre-existing role for the pair. I feel the
latter is a bit more appropriate.

The KVS and the pam backends were simply accepting the request, while
the LDAP backend was raising an error. So be consistent, and always
return 409.

Change-Id: I7328d2932f6907d48e6422674eeeee22dc7a7149
"}, {'created': '2012-07-03 19:43:56.000000000', 'message': "Return a 409 error when adding a second time a role to user/tenant

When a user/tenant pair already has a role and there is a request to add
the role to the pair, we can choose to either return 200 and let the
client feel it's alright to do so, or return a 409 error (Conflict) to
inform the client of the pre-existing role for the pair. I feel the
latter is a bit more appropriate.

The KVS and the pam backends were simply accepting the request, while
the LDAP backend was raising an error. So be consistent, and always
return 409.

Change-Id: I7328d2932f6907d48e6422674eeeee22dc7a7149
"}, {'created': '2012-07-04 06:02:39.000000000', 'message': "Return a 409 error when adding a second time a role to user/tenant

Fix bug 999594.

When a user/tenant pair already has a role and there is a request to add
the role to the pair, we can choose to either return 200 and let the
client feel it's alright to do so, or return a 409 error (Conflict) to
inform the client of the pre-existing role for the pair. I feel the
latter is a bit more appropriate.

The KVS and the pam backends were simply accepting the request, while
the LDAP backend was raising an error. So be consistent, and always
return 409.

Change-Id: I7328d2932f6907d48e6422674eeeee22dc7a7149
"}]
commit_message:
Return a 409 error when adding a second time a role to user/tenant

Fix bug 999594.

When a user/tenant pair already has a role and there is a request to add
the role to the pair, we can choose to either return 200 and let the
client feel it's alright to do so, or return a 409 error (Conflict) to
inform the client of the pre-existing role for the pair. I feel the
latter is a bit more appropriate.

The KVS and the pam backends were simply accepting the request, while
the LDAP backend was raising an error. So be consistent, and always
return 409.

Change-Id: I7328d2932f6907d48e6422674eeeee22dc7a7149

commit_message:
notify calling process we are ready to serve

Fixes bug 980037 again

Systemd notification should be sent in-process, otherwise systemd might
miss the subprocess sending notification.
See systemd bug https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=820448

Change-Id: Iccc51cf77af5598ee6b4c3cd69a12a7ee9fc2eb5

commit_message:
Make sure user dict has id key before checking against it

The user dict passed to the update_user() method doesn't
always have a key called 'id'. Make sure we check for
the existence of the key before getting its value.

Change-Id: I760fb6d99aa517a6877d8fb0124da78b0ec5f4b7
Fixes: LP #1022411

commit_message:
Allow image filtering by custom properties

A user can filter a list of images by passing in a 'properties'
sub-dictionary inside of the 'filters' keyword argumen to
ImageManager.list(). The same functionality can be used through
the CLI through the use of one or more'--property-filter' options.

Related to bp glance-client-parity.

Change-Id: I7d119174d83faa894dde557e1944289de296a02c

commit_message:
Changes to run smoke tests for Tempest first, then full

Modifies the gate job to run Tempest's smoke tests *first*
and then only if the smoke tests succeed, then execute
the entire non-smoke test Tempest suite.

Removes the now defunct DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_TESTS variable
and puts in place a DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_FULL variable that
is set to 1 when the tempest project itself is being gated.

Change-Id: Id8d2701ebbfd2807fc43f264147f018fd4dfea8c

commit_message:
Add --timeout option to cli

Create a --timeout option to allow users to provide a custom timeout
for requests from the command line. The timeout functonality already
exists in both v1 and v2 client classes.

Related to bp glance-client-parity

Change-Id: Ic91de5eae2824b37f6aad3adc5fda28b9674250e

[{'created': '2012-07-09 16:47:08.000000000', 'message': "Add indexes to MongoDB driver

Add some compound key indexes for the typical queries
run by the engine. Separate variations are used for
queries with user_id and project_id because they are
usually mutually exclusive and because of the way the
indexes are computed and stored the database won't take
advantage of an index using both.

bug 1021324

Change-Id: I9d6bbd1e7ac5a633fa3ead131a4ebc0a83226633
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Add indexes to MongoDB driver

Add some compound key indexes for the typical queries
run by the engine. Separate variations are used for
queries with user_id and project_id because they are
usually mutually exclusive and because of the way the
indexes are computed and stored the database won't take
advantage of an index using both.

bug 1021324

Change-Id: I9d6bbd1e7ac5a633fa3ead131a4ebc0a83226633
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9316/'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-07-09 16:39:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hm... will these issues of path-swizzling be rendered moot when openstack-common becomes a proper library?  If so, a half-assed solution like mine seems called for :)'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-07-09 16:39:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

$ grep -Iir getlogger *

This suggests that at the moment, loggers in openstack-common are only ever set up using __name__.  Is that what you meant?

Furthermore, if a logger were configured with an explicit path in common, it would presumably look like this:

LOG = logging.getLogger('openstack.common.module')

...in which case this patch would fix things rather than break them."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-07-09 16:39:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Update strings like 'openstack.common.notifier.driver'.

I was running into trouble with driver names that were generically named
in common but need to point to specific objects within nova.

Change-Id: Ie75761c73a855b067b1bcec651a1bb998deba9f4

commit_message:
Make reboot work for halted xenapi instances

Fixes bug 1022199

This also will catch exceptions and make sure to reset the task_state,
while still generating an instance fault.

Change-Id: I122a1422b8e5731bc484414736ab44e60d4c9830

commit_message:
Add a new module for use in consuming versioninfo.

The new tag-based versioning produces files that we can consume that tell
us the versioning. That's all well and good, but what good is automatically
generated versioning if there are no apis to consume it. This is derived
from work to add those to nova and python-swiftclient.

Change-Id: I91568ef28a9ed7e7365f66bca2294670df6e0c41

commit_message:
Modify import paths to match the namespace of common.

Frequently we'll try to import a module from common with a
name like 'openstack.common.foobar' which will fail because
the actual file is 'nova.openstack.common.foobar'.  This patch
fixes such broken module paths before loading.

Change-Id: I38a220817850afef921e06bb3427cd25644b2906

commit_message:
Fixes bug 1020557 by updating introduction_to_xen.xml

Cherry picked from:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9277/

Other hypervisors list the image types supported, and
a basic pointer to the flags required to enable the support.
This change adds these details for Xen and XenAPI

To ensure consitency with these additions have corrected
several other references to Xen, XenServer and XenAPI.

I have also adjusted the dpi of the XenServer diagram
so it is visible in the pdf version of the document

Change-Id: Ic9d933ad3c34e032b0529bd9efce4c37d300c7aa

subject: Fixes behavior of the 'check-all' checkbox
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-29 00:56:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-merge/913/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/1068/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python26/332/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-python27/334/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/6820/consoleFull : FAILURE
"}, {'account_id': 1699, 'date': '2012-06-29 01:02:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

freaking jenkins.'}, {'account_id': 1699, 'date': '2012-06-29 01:06:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Please ignore the jenkins failure it appears to be a problem getting the devstack environment running.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-06-29 14:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Although this patch seems to fix the problem, it doesn't fix what is causing it. The problem here is that the 'on' event handler on the wrapper divs:

    $("div.table_wrapper, div.modal_wrapper").on("click", ':checkbox', function (evt) {

is being included in the validate_button() function, which is being executed from forms, and from modals, and is called once on page load, but after before the other . If you try to open a modal, and close it, you will see that the check-all checkboxes work as expected. That's because the on('click') delegate is being applied *BEFORE* one other on('click') delegate on the same checkbox, and it checks for checked checkboxes before they are actually checked.
When you open a modal on the page and close it, it appends the on(click) delegate after the other one, and it actually is being executed twice. If you open again a modal - it will doesn't work again as expected. Next time - will work.. and so on...

To really solve the problem - just move the whole on('click') delegate from above at the line where you made the edit.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-07-04 11:49:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-07-04 11:50:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-07-04 11:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

This should have fixed the problem.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-04 12:01:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Sorry haven't gotten back.  Been moving.  Good work. LGTM"}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-07-05 20:32:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Fixes behavior of the 'check-all' checkbox

in tables. Currently the on('click')
delegate is being invoked several times
from the wrong place, thus allowing another
on('click') delegate to be executed before
this one, which changes the expected behavior.

Fixes bug 1019088

Change-Id: Iba2b3549090f7bd42fc8b029ed42163951cb9e22

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-05 07:45:47.000000000', 'message': 'Simplified command to get glance-api processes pid

Before:	   "ps -fu $USER | grep glance-api | grep -v grep | awk '{print $2}' | sort -nr"

Now:   	   "pgrep -u $USER -f glance-api | sort -nr"

Change-Id: I0b19704a1c73503cb27d503626088d1aecb020e8
'}]
commit_message:
Simplified command to get glance-api processes pid

Before:	   "ps -fu $USER | grep glance-api | grep -v grep | awk '{print $2}' | sort -nr"

Now:   	   "pgrep -u $USER -f glance-api | sort -nr"

Change-Id: I0b19704a1c73503cb27d503626088d1aecb020e8

commit_message:
Optimized and reduced the scope of smoke tests

* Factored images smoke test into seperate class
* Removed any tests from smoke that are extensions
* Moved list servers smoke tests into part of general server creation smoke test
* Overall smoke test execution time reduced by 50%

Change-Id: I4838cea39d3338033fd2d4400d9622b55c38ff3c

commit_message:
Add skip for disabled user test until associated bug is fixed

Turns out the PUT /users/<USER_ID/enabled call in Keystone
admin API extension is broken until the fix for the associated
bug is in. This adds the skip until that is done.

Change-Id: Ia5d032ebc68c99c9db40e8d96776d81f61a47aec
Fixes: LP 1018635

subject: Fixes bug 1020557 by updating introduction_to_xen.xml
messages:
[{'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-07-04 06:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

one in-line comment for your thoughts'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-04 08:23:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-04 23:05:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It's great to see the Xen docs being updated here.

As someone without any experience with Xen, I'm a little confused by the xenapi_connection_* flags.

In particular, what service is the xenapi_connection_url supposed to point to? The example says "http://your_management_ip_address", but I don't know what "management" refers to here. Does it point to an xapi service, or something else? (nova-api service?) Is this typically the same IP address as the compute service, or do the different compute nodes all point to the same management IP address?'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-04 23:07:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Also, in the "Further reading" section, it points to the wiki page and describes that as "Latests XenServer and OpenStack documentation". Is the intent going forward to keep the wiki more up to date than these docs?'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-05 09:15:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-05 09:20:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi, some good points. Hopefully it reads a bit more clearly now. The diagram probably helps quite a lot with making things clear.

I just moved the wiki to be called "further information" because long run I want all the information in these docs before the release ships! But always good to refer them to the other documents.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-07-05 11:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-07-07 22:36:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Fixes bug 1020557 by updating introduction_to_xen.xml

Other hypervisors list the image types supported, and
a basic pointer to the flags required to enable the support.
This change adds these details for Xen and XenAPI

To ensure consitency with these additions have corrected
several other references to Xen, XenServer and XenAPI.

I have also adjusted the dpi of the XenServer diagram
so it is visible in the pdf version of the document

Change-Id: Ic9d933ad3c34e032b0529bd9efce4c37d300c7aa
